short_description: BETTER JOB PROSPECTS IN THE MEKONG
long_description: The Mekong region contains some of today's most dynamic economies of ASEAN (the Association of Southeast Asian Nations). All these economies (with the exception of Thailand) are overcoming legacies of heavy-handed centralized governments in which the private sector had a very limited role. Since the 1990s, foreign investment and a vast pool of workers have catapulted the economies of Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, and more recently Burma, to the category of fastest growing low-income countries. Their garments, electronics, food processing and other industries have rapidly joined global value chains and employed millions of workers. As these countries continue their fast economic transformation, the generation of more jobs with better working conditions for the growing numbers of youth is becoming a major challenge. The project will contribute to addressing this challenge by supporting a regional network of researchers to examine current policies and practices to upgrade skills and improve working conditions for young, low-skilled workers, mainly women and those belonging to ethnic communities. A leading think tank (the Cambodia Development Resource Institute, CDRI) will be the hub of the network, which will launch a first-ever competitive research call for up to 12 research ideas from other regional think tanks and non-government organizations. Some of the subprojects would include pilot ideas to be scalable in the future. CDRI will provide oversight of the research and link it to the wider community of policymakers, private sector and civil society in the Greater Mekong region and ASEAN.

title: Biological Control of Pests in Mekong Eucalypt Plantations
short_description: BIOLOGICAL CONTROL OF PESTS IN MEKONG EUCALYPT PLANTATIONS
long_description: The gall wasp (Leptocybe invasa), an Australian-origin insect pest, is threatening the viability and sustainability of the expanding eucalypt plantations in the Mekong Region. This project aims to investigate biological control options to overcome losses caused by the wasp and enhance the productivity of eucalypt plantations, directly benefiting plantation growers, communities and smallholder farmers. Research will determine the distribution and economic impacts of the gall wasp in this region. It will identify and test the effectiveness of potential biological control agents in quarantine and field sites, to control the pest and promote sustainable forestry. The project will also involve regional workshops to develop strategic and operational plans, and training activities and materials on techniques for control agent release, monitoring and dissemination.

title: Biosecurity market - Cambodia
short_description: BIOSECURITY MARKET - CAMBODIA
long_description: Smallholder farmers who own cattle in Cambodia have limited access to domestic and export markets which are increasingly demanding high and consistent quantity and quality beef. Livestock owners also suffer significant production and financial losses as a result of disease outbreak. The Cambodian Strategy for Livestock Production (2011) seeks to improve market participation as well as reducing associated risks of disease. Sustainable market chains ensure that all stakeholders in the market chain have economic incentives to work with smallholders to improve management of biosecurity and production. This project supports the development of a market chain that encourages smallholders in South East Cambodia (of which 85% currently own cattle) to access the Ho Chi Minh City, Phnom Penh and Siem Reap markets.

title: CAM: GMS Rehabilitation of the Railway in Cambodia
short_description: CAM: GMS REHABILITATION OF THE RAILWAY IN CAMBODIA
long_description: The proposed Project will restore the Cambodia's railway infrastructure by rehabilitating its existing track and reestablishing Cambodia's rail connection with Thailand. This will be initiated in 2007 for completion in 2009. The railway's operations will be improved through restructuring, which is ongoing and will be completed in 2007 with award to a private railway operator of a concession to operate the railway commercially for a period of 33 years under a PPP arrangement. Restructuring is implemented through an ADTA that advises the Government on the future structure of the railway subsector and provides transaction advisory for selection of the PPP Railway Operator. The PPP Railway Operator will be selected after competitive international bidding for the concession. The rehabilitation investment and the associated restructuring will together set the stage for efficient rail services, which in turn realizes the Project's objectives: improving the transport sector's efficiency by increasing the diversity of transport modes and routes, and resurrecting the railway on a sustainable basis.

title: Cambodia Agricultural Value Chain Phase 2 - Design and Procurement
short_description: CAMBODIA AGRICULTURAL VALUE CHAIN PHASE 2 - DESIGN AND PROCUREMENT
long_description: The Cambodia Agricultural Value Chain (CAVAC) Program Phase 2 aims to reduce rural poverty by improving the productivity and incomes of smallholder farmers in Cambodia. and take into consideration the changing agricultural systems and priorities of the Cambodian Government. CAVAC Phase II will also continue its market-based approach that includes partnership with the private sector and Government to strengthen market systems, promote greater investment and add value in agricultural crop value chains. The Australia-Cambodia Joint Aid Program Strategy currently includes separate objectives related to both Agriculture and Rural Development, as well as Infrastructure. Activities under this initiative will examine topics related to both sectoral objectives, to determine any potential areas of cross-over that might be included under Phase II of CAVAC. The estimated total value of this investment is $66 million over 6 years with expected implementation stage starting 2015-16.

title: Cambodia Australian Scholarship Initiative
short_description: CAMBODIA AUSTRALIAN SCHOLARSHIP INITIATIVE
long_description: The Cambodia Australian Scholarships Program aims to improve human resource capacity in Cambodia consistent with the sectoral, regional, trans boundary and emerging priorities of the Cambodia-Australia development cooperation program and the broader bilateral relationship. The scholarship program will: provide individuals with the competencies and capabilities that will enable them to contribute to Cambodia's development using their new knowledge effectively; help address the human resource needs of Cambodian institutions; and enhance mutual understanding and contribute to linkages between individuals in Australia and Cambodia and within the region. The total value of this initiative is $8.0 million over 6 years, starting 2012-13.

title: Cambodia Communication Assistance Project Phase 2
short_description: CAMBODIA COMMUNICATION ASSISTANCE PROJECT PHASE 2
long_description: The Cambodia Communication Assistance Project Phase 1 mid-term evaluation recommended a new phase to build on the unique success of the phase 1, extending governance-focused capacity building to other provinces to build a network of government radio stations which have the reach and critical mass to support improved governance at the local/provincial level.  This Investment focuses on enhancing the successes of participating PDIs and the Kratie community radio rather than extending reach to other provinces.  The overall objective of this investment is to contribute to the achievement of better governance in Cambodia. The final destination is a local and sub-national situation whereby there is better government accountability and transparency, with evidence of contribution from citizens expressing their views and holding government to account. The purpose is the creation of a dialogue platform that enables citizens to gain access to elected officials, local authorities and civil society organisations (CSOs), leading to improved citizen access to quality information with which they can seek better accountability and transparency.  The intermediate outcomes are: 1. Enhanced capability of PDI in relation to citizen voice and government responsiveness. 2. Strengthened influence of citizen voice in government accountability and transparency. 3. Greater transparency and accountability of authorities towards citizen issues.

title: Cambodia Community Development Fund: Reducing Rural Poverty
short_description: CAMBODIA COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND: REDUCING RURAL POVERTY
long_description: The Community Development Fund (CDF) contributes to the development of Cambodia's civil society, particularly in rural areas. It aims to: (1) reduce rural poverty through agricultural development, agribusiness and increasing food and livelihood security; (2) strengthen the health system with a focus on maternal and child health; (3) improve the protection and promotion of individual rights and responsibilities; and (4) strengthen good governance, eliminate discrimination against women and ensure disability inclusion. This initiative was initially established to run over a three financial year period however has been extended with extra funds supporting existing activities. The total value of this initiative is $4.6 million over 5 years, starting 2010-11.

title: Cambodia Development Research Forum II
short_description: CAMBODIA DEVELOPMENT RESEARCH FORUM II
long_description: Cambodia s research community is still rebuilding from decades of turmoil that included civil war and a period of ethnic and intellectual cleansing under the Khmer Rouge. Its development research community remains dispersed and unconnected, though there are pockets of strong capacity. IDRC was one of the first international donors active in Cambodia, beginning in 1991, and it continues to support the reconstruction of an active research community.This grant enables the Cambodia Development Resource Institute to collaborate with seven partners to continue the work of the Cambodia Development Research Forum. The key ideas underpinning the Forum emerged from a meeting of all IDRC-supported groups and individuals in Cambodia in 2007. In the Forum s first phase, annual research symposia were held, and a Web platform was established to link researchers. The goal of this second phase is to further strengthen the capacity of the Cambodian development research community. In this latest phase, five research interest groups are facilitating interaction and learning among development researchers, government officials, members of parliament, and the media on pressing development issues. The Forum continues to organize its annual development symposium. It is supported by an Internet-based platform (www.drfcambodia.net) with some 500 members. Additional activities include the production of research synthesis and policy papers, and the organization of research workshops and policy roundtables.

short_description: CAMBODIA INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT 2013-2020
long_description: Funding under this initiative provides support for infrastructure investments in Cambodia. While Cambodia has experienced high rates of economic growth over the past twenty years, continued development gains are hampered by low levels of infrastructure development particularly in rural areas. Activities under this initiative will be cofinanced infrastructure activities that align with Australia's broader strategic interests in Cambodia, particularly economic growth.  The initial investment is $7.6million, for an activity that will be implemented until 2020, with other activities possible over time.

title: Cambodia Law And Justice Program
short_description: CAMBODIA LAW AND JUSTICE PROGRAM
long_description: The Cambodia Law and Justice Sector Support aims to enable prosperous, safe and secure communities in Cambodia by contributing to building safer communities and reducing overcrowding in prisons by helping Cambodia put into practice its relevant policies and laws. The design has four end-of-program outcomes: criminal justice is managed to reduce prison overcrowding; women, youth and children are safer and communities have less crime; communities, police, courts and prisons use data to support management; and mutually accountable partnership. The total value of this initiative is $15.0 million over 4 years, starting 2012-13.

title: Cambodia managed to reduce its HIV prevalence from 2 percent in 1998 to 0.7 percent in 2010 which is mainly attributed to the 100 percent condom use program among entertainment workers. Despite these results, Cambodia still faces challenges in addressing HIV, with more than 56,200 people living
short_description: CAMBODIA MANAGED TO REDUCE ITS HIV PREVALENCE FROM 2 PERCENT IN 1998 TO 0.7 PERCENT IN 2010 WHICH IS MAINLY ATTRIBUTED TO THE 100 PERCENT CONDOM US
long_description: Cambodia managed to reduce its HIV prevalence from 2 percent in 1998 to 0.7 percent in 2010 which is mainly attributed to the 100 percent condom use program among entertainment workers. Despite these results, Cambodia still faces challenges in addressing HIV, with more than 56,200 people living with HIV as of 2010, of which 46,000 are in need for antiretroviral treatment (ART). The program aims to maintain comprehensive care and treatment, including anti-retroviral drug provision, for all people living with HIV in need of treatment up to 2015 and to provide sole funding for ART. It seeks to maintain Cambodia's dedication to Universal Access by addressing challenges identified by the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS III such as reducing financial cost of ART and continuing of integration of the Continuum of Care (CoC) framework into the wider health system to better reach Most-at-Risk Populations (MARPs). The grant activities strengthen coordination and monitoring capacity within and across national and provincial multi-sectoral initiatives and the scale up of illicit drug related HIV/AIDS programs as a key component to achieve Cambodia's Universal Access targets.

title: Cambodia Programme for Sustainable and Inclusive Growth in the Fisheries Sector: Aquaculture (CaPFish Aquaculture)
short_description: CAMBODIA PROGRAMME FOR SUSTAINABLE AND INCLUSIVE GROWTH IN THE FISHERIES SECTOR: AQUACULTURE (CAPFISH AQUACULTURE)
long_description: The action seeks to ensure a more sustainable, climate-resilient and inclusive growth in theCambodian aquaculture sector, in order to increase food security, improve nutrition and support socio-economic development

title: Cambodia Road Asset Maintenance Project
short_description: CAMBODIA ROAD ASSET MAINTENANCE PROJECT
long_description: The Cambodia Road Asset Maintenance Project supports the World Bank's and Asian Development Bank's Road Asset Maintenance Project in Cambodia which aims to improve the maintenance of priority Cambodian roads and to build the capacity of the Ministry of Public Works & Transport-Directorate General of Public Works to plan and maintain the road network. The total value of this initiative is $6.0 million over 4 years, starting 2007-08.

title: Cambodia: Delivering Better Health
short_description: CAMBODIA: DELIVERING BETTER HEALTH
long_description: Funding under this initiative provides support for the Cambodia Delivering Better Health Program through the provision of financial support to the World Bank, funding to non-government organisation to support: implementation of the Fast Track Initiative to reduce maternal and child mortality; essential health care for the poorest Cambodians across health facilities; provision of performance-based funding; building basic health infrastructure; and provision of essential medical equipment. The total value of this initiative is $124 million over 12 years, starting 2006-07.

title: Cambodian Crocodile Conservation Programme: Ensuring The Future Of The Critically Endangered Siamese Crocodile In The Wild
short_description: CAMBODIAN CROCODILE CONSERVATION PROGRAMME: ENSURING THE FUTURE OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SIAMESE CROCODILE IN THE WILD
long_description: This project will attempt to double the wild population of Siamese crocodiles by 2017 and to leverage the species as a flagship for conserving threatened rivers and wetlands in Cambodia. Specific activities include: (1) enhancing the viability of wild populations through restocking at least one additional wetland under the National Crocodile Re-Introduction and Reinforcement Strategy and Action Plan by 2015; (2) strengthening community management of crocodile sanctuaries established under precious CEACF support, and developing management plans for at least two new sanctuaries; (3) increasing awareness so that at least 10% of Cambodians are aware that the Siamese crocodile is indigenous, rare, and protected by law, to be accomplished through surveys of the public, an enhanced education program at Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Centre aimed at reaching 50,000 people per year, and frequent features on crocodiles and this project in various forms of media; (4) monitoring the crocodile population and disseminating project methods, results, and impacts to benefit further conservation planning in Cambodia and throughout the species range.

title: Cambodian Higher Education Policy Research
short_description: CAMBODIAN HIGHER EDUCATION POLICY RESEARCH
long_description: The Cambodia Australian Scholarships Program aims to improve human resource capacity in Cambodia consistent with the sectoral, regional, trans boundary and emerging priorities of the Cambodia-Australia development cooperation program and the broader bilateral relationship. The scholarship program will: provide individuals with the competencies and capabilities that will enable them to contribute to Cambodia's development using their new knowledge effectively; help address the human resource needs of Cambodian institutions; and enhance mutual understanding and contribute to linkages between individuals in Australia and Cambodia and within the region. The total value of this initiative is $8.0 million over 6 years, starting 2012-13.

title: Cambodian Rehabilitation of Railway: Administered Infrastructure Support
short_description: CAMBODIAN REHABILITATION OF RAILWAY: ADMINISTERED INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT
long_description: The Rehabilitation of Railway in Cambodia Project supports the Asian Development Bank to upgrade the national railway of Cambodia: southern railway (254km from Sihanoukville to Phnom Penh) and northern railway (388 km from Phnom Penh to Poipet on Thai border). The majority of this funding will purchase rail sleepers, fund rehabilitation activities, and undertake related public works and upgrades at railway stations. The improved rail line will increase container traffic and trade between Cambodia and its neighbours, and reduce costs associated with road maintenance. The total value of this initiative is $27.1 million over a 7 year period, starting 2008-09.

title: Cambodians Deported from Thailand Support
short_description: CAMBODIANS DEPORTED FROM THAILAND SUPPORT
long_description: A surge of Cambodian migrants has been crossing the Poipet border from Thailand in fear of arrest by the Thai military, following widespread layoffs of both legal and informal workers, in the wake of the Thai military coup in May 2014.  Many are arriving with no money. The International Organization for Migrations (IOM) Cambodia has issued a call for assistance to respond to the issue, including by providing transport assistance. Funding  under this initiative represents Australia's contribution and will be delivered via a replenishment of the IOM's Emergency Fund. The total value of this investment is $45,000 to be expensed during the 2014-15 financial year.

title: Capacity Building of Cambodias Local Organizations - Civic Participation
short_description: CAPACITY BUILDING OF CAMBODIAS LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS - CIVIC PARTICIPATION
long_description: The Capacity Building of Cambodia's Local Organizations project will directly support USAID Forward goals by promoting sustainable development through the use of local partnerships. The project will support the development of new partnerships with local organizations and strengthen the skills of existing partners across all technical sectors. Environment partners in particular will gain from this activity and will in turn lead to more effective programming that will often support Cambodia low emissions development strategy. The project will help local organizations improve their financial management and human resource systems, develop strategic and operational plans, and strengthen their monitoring and evaluation systems. This project will also support USAID in implementing risk-mitigation procedures through pre-award assessments of potential local organizations and financial reviews of current partners.

title: Civil Society Grants: Improve Access to Water, Sanitation and Hygiene
short_description: CIVIL SOCIETY GRANTS: IMPROVE ACCESS TO WATER, SANITATION AND HYGIENE
long_description: The Civil Society Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Fund is a global grant program for civil society organisations to deliver activities that improve access to water, sanitation and hygiene for approximately 1.8 million people across Africa, Asia and the Pacific. Key components of the WASH Fund include: development of a peer reviewed design of the Fund; competitive selection process; provision of grants to civil society organisations to deliver water, sanitation and hygiene activities; fund management; and the establishment of a dedicated Monitoring, Evaluation and Review Panel (MERP). The total value of this initiative is $102.6 million over 7 years, starting 2011-12.

short_description: CLEARING FOR RESULTS PHASE 2 (2011-2015): SUPPORTS LANDMINE CLEARANCE IN CAMBODIA THROUGH A MULTI-DONOR FACILITY
long_description: Clearing for Results Phase II supports landmine clearance in Cambodia through a multi-donor facility managed by the UNDP in partnership with the Royal Government of Cambodia. the objectives of Clearing for Results Phase II are: mine action policy and strategic frameworks to ensure resources are effectively allocated to national priorities and maximise the land available for local development; the Cambodian Mine Action and Victim Assistance Authority is equipped with technical and functional capabilities; and maximise release of mine/explosive remnant of war affected land, promoting efficiency and transparency. The total value of this initiative is $10.2 million over 5 years, starting 2010-11.

title: Community Development Fund (CDF) 2010-13
short_description: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT FUND (CDF) 2010-13
long_description: The Community Development Fund (CDF) contributes to the development of Cambodia's civil society, particularly in rural areas. It aims to: (1) reduce rural poverty through agricultural development, agribusiness and increasing food and livelihood security; (2) strengthen the health system with a focus on maternal and child health; (3) improve the protection and promotion of individual rights and responsibilities; and (4) strengthen good governance, eliminate discrimination against women and ensure disability inclusion. This initiative was initially established to run over a three financial year period however has been extended with extra funds supporting existing activities. The total value of this initiative is $4.6 million over 5 years, starting 2010-11.

title: Community Policing Initiative in Cambodia
short_description: COMMUNITY POLICING INITIATIVE IN CAMBODIA
long_description: Funding under this investment supports collaboration between the Government of Australia and the Royal Government of Cambodia to support the Community Policing Initiative (CPI), supporting the Cambodia National Police (CNP) to develop a community policing modality at national and subnational levels. The CPI aims to build community policing in Cambodia that is well managed, inclusive, and delivers effective policing services to Cambodian citizens through: strengthened community policing management and oversight; enhanced community policing performance effectiveness; enhanced police-community relations; and enhanced sustainability of community policing approaches. CPI will also support CNP to put focus its community policing approach to address gender-based violence issues. The total value of this investment is $4.3 million over 5 years, starting 2014-15.

title: Conservation Of An Important Population Of The Critically Endangered Southern River Terrapin,..Batagur Affinis, In Southern Cambodia
short_description: CONSERVATION OF AN IMPORTANT POPULATION OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SOUTHERN RIVER TERRAPIN,..BATAGUR AFFINIS, IN SOUTHERN CAMBODIA
long_description: 'Conservation of an important population of critically endangered Southern River Terrapin, Batagur affineis, in Southern Cambodia.' In partnership with Wildlife Conservation Society, this project will improve the global conservation status of Batagur affinis by reducing threats to, and improving recruitment in an important remnant population in Cambodia. Specific activities include: (1) expand and increase effectiveness of patrols aimed at discovering additional nests using the SMART (Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool) method originally developed by WCS and USFWS for tiger conservation; (2) conduct in situ nest incubation and protection for all nests found in the wild that will be guarded by wardens; (3) transfer hatchling turtles from field incubation studies to head-starting facilities; (4) select and release 25 head-started turtles with an acoustic tag; (5) monitor turtles post release using an omni directional hydrophone and underwater automated recording stations.

long_description: Phnom Bakheng temple is the most visited temple at Angkor Archaeological ParkÌ_a World Heritage siteÌ_and one of the greatest cultural achievements of the Khmer Kingdom. This project, which continues work begun under previous grants, involves the conservation of the east side of the temple.

title: Consolidation de la prise en charge des jeunes enfants ‰ÛÁ travers le renforcement des communes de la province de Siem Reap - Cambodge
short_description: CONSOLIDATION DE LA PRISE EN CHARGE DES JEUNES ENFANTS åÀ TRAVERS LE RENFORCEMENT DES COMMUNES DE LA PROVINCE DE SIEM REAP - CAMBODGE

title: Consolidation of support for young children (ECCD -Early Childhood Care and Development) through the strengthening of communes in the province of Siem
short_description: CONSOLIDATION OF SUPPORT FOR YOUNG CHILDREN (ECCD -EARLY CHILDHOOD CARE AND DEVELOPMENT) THROUGH THE STRENGTHENING OF COMMUNES IN THE PROVINCE OF SIEM
long_description: Background :  Le projet a pour objectif le dÌöveloppement de l'ECCD (Early Childhood Care and Development) ‰ÛÁ travers un renforcement des compÌötences en la matiÌÜre des structures dÌöcentralisÌöes (22 communes). Il vient en appui ‰ÛÁ la StratÌögie Nationale du Cambodge pour l'‰Û_ducation et au Plan d'action National pour l'ECCD et mettant en pratique des Standards Minimum du MinistÌÜre de l'Education pour l'ECCD (janvier 2015). Le projet s'aligne totalement sur ces documents de rÌöfÌörence nationale et tentera en mÌme temps de dÌömontrer comment ils peuvent Ìtre mis en pratique de maniÌÜre novatrice, Ìöconomique et durable, en investissant et en collaborant avec les structures dÌöcentralisÌöes.  -Specific objective :  Un modÌÜle d'ECCD intÌögrÌö et durable est dÌöfini et mis en oeuvre par les communes. Il est alignÌö sur les standards minimum nationaux, assure des services de qualitÌö et amÌöliore les rÌösultats pÌödagogiques des enfants de la province de Siem Reap  -Intended results :  Les groupes de parents mis en place par les communes ont assurÌö un changement positif durable des comportements en termes de parentalitÌö en faveur du groupe d'‰Û_ge 0-3 ans. Les Ìötablissements prÌö-scolaires mis en place par les communes ont assurÌö un environnement stimulant positif durable et de qualitÌö pour tous les enfants de 3 ‰ÛÁ 6 ans. Les conseils communaux ainsi que les dÌöpartements dÌöconcentrÌös du MinistÌÜre de l'Education sont renforcÌös pour appuyer effectivement le dÌöveloppement pÌödagogique et la gestion de services d'ECCD Les parties prenantes ont partagÌö leur expÌörience de mise en place d'un environnement communal durable et stimulant gr‰Û_ce aux activitÌös de parentalitÌö et au dÌöveloppement du prÌö-scolaire avec le gouvernement pour amÌöliorer les connaissances sur les politiques et pratiques de l'ECCD, en appui au plan national d'action ECCD   - Consolidation of support for young children (ECCD -Early Childhood Care and Development) through the strengthening of communes in the province of Siem Reap;

title: Constitutions, Laws, and Legal Systems
short_description: CONSTITUTIONS, LAWS, AND LEGAL SYSTEMS
long_description: Support the development of constitutions, laws, and legal systems that are derived through democratic processes and are consistent with international human rights standards. Ensure that the public participates in the legal process as appropriate, perceives laws as legitimate and worthy of adherence, and respects the authority of law and legal institutions. Includes efforts to end impunity and enable peaceful transitions to democracy, as well as efforts to harmonize customary or religious law with state-based legal systems.

title: Continued achievement of Universal Access of HIV/Sexually Transmitted Infections Prevention, Treatment and Care services in Cambodia
short_description: CONTINUED ACHIEVEMENT OF UNIVERSAL ACCESS OF HIV/SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS PREVENTION, TREATMENT AND CARE SERVICES IN CAMBODIA
long_description: Cambodia managed to reduce its HIV prevalence from 2 percent in 1998 to 0.7 percent in 2010 which is mainly attributed to the '100 percent condom use' program among entertainment workers.  Despite these results, Cambodia still faces challenges in addressing HIV, with more than 56,200 people living with HIV as of 2010, of which 46,000 are in need for antiretroviral treatment (ART).  The program aims to maintain comprehensive care and treatment, including anti-retroviral drug provision, for all people living with HIV in need of treatment up to 2015 and to provide sole funding for ART.  It seeks to maintain Cambodia's dedication to Universal Access by addressing challenges identified by the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS III such as reducing financial cost of ART and continuing of integration of the Continuum of Care (CoC) framework into the wider health system to better reach Most-at-Risk Populations (MARPs).  The grant activities strengthen coordination and monitoring capacity within and across national and provincial multi-sectoral initiatives and the scale up of illicit drug related HIV/AIDS programs as a key component to achieve Cambodia's Universal Access targets.

short_description: CONTINUED ACHIEVEMENT OF UNIVERSAL ACCESS OF HIV/SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED INFECTIONS PREVENTION, TREATMENT AND CARE SERVICES IN CAMBODIA
long_description: Cambodia managed to reduce its HIV prevalence from 2 percent in 1998 to 0.7 percent in 2010 which is mainly attributed to the '100 percent condom use' program among entertainment workers. Despite these results, Cambodia still faces challenges in addressing HIV, with more than 56,200 people living with HIV as of 2010, of which 46,000 are in need for antiretroviral treatment (ART). The program aims to maintain comprehensive care and treatment, including anti-retroviral drug provision, for all people living with HIV in need of treatment up to 2015 and to provide sole funding for ART. It seeks to maintain Cambodia's dedication to Universal Access by addressing challenges identified by the National Strategic Plan for HIV/AIDS III such as reducing financial cost of ART and continuing of integration of the Continuum of Care (CoC) framework into the wider health system to better reach Most-at-Risk Populations (MARPs). The grant activities strengthen coordination and monitoring capacity within and across national and provincial multi-sectoral initiatives and the scale up of illicit drug related HIV/AIDS programs as a key component to achieve Cambodia's Universal Access targets.

Le secteur de l'Ìöducation et de la formation professionnelle tant formelle qu'informelle reste toujours le secteur privilÌögiÌö de l'APEFE ( 55% de ses actions) sachant par ailleurs que les quatre autres secteurs sont aussi apprÌöhendÌös de maniÌÜre globale au travers d'activitÌös de formation comme la SantÌö (20%), l'Agriculture (19%) et la Gouvernance (6%).  -Specific objective :  L'adÌöquation entre formation/emploi au Cambodge, Laos et Viet Nam est renforcÌöe suivant l'APC dans un Ìöchantillon de filiÌÜres et d'Ìötablissements en dÌöveloppant l'entreprenariat.   -Intended results :  L'essentiel de l'intervention consistera ‰ÛÁ accÌölÌörer un processus rÌögional dÌöj‰ÛÁ engagÌö mais qui doit encore Ìtre consolidÌö et mis en Ì¼uvre. Ce programme nÌöcessitera ainsi un dialogue permanent entre tous les acteurs concernÌös et se basera sur le renforcement des capacitÌös des hommes et des organisations, condition indispensable ‰ÛÁ sa rÌöussite. R1 : les partenaires, mutualisent, rationnalisent, capitalisent des systÌÜmes FPT au travers d'un partenariat et d'une coopÌöration efficace R2 : les capacitÌös de formulation et de gestion des politiques de la FPT ont ÌötÌö renforcÌöes en rÌöfÌörence ‰ÛÁ l'approche sectorielle R3 : les capacitÌös de rÌögulation et de suivi-Ìövaluation des systÌÜmes FPT ont ÌötÌö renforcÌöes R4 : Des programmes pilotes (rÌöfÌörentiels de mÌötier, rÌöfÌörentiels de formation, guides de formation, guides d'Ìövaluation, formation de ressources humaines) ont ÌötÌö mis en place, expÌörimentÌös et ÌövaluÌös selon l'approche par compÌötence dans un Ìöchantillon ciblÌö de filiÌÜres et d'Ìötablissement  -

title: Control and Prevention of Malaria (CAP-Malaria) - Malaria
short_description: CONTROL AND PREVENTION OF MALARIA (CAP-MALARIA) - MALARIA
long_description: Control and Prevention of Malaria (CAP-Malaria)

title: Control and Prevention of Malaria (CAP-Malaria) - Malaria
short_description: CONTROL AND PREVENTION OF MALARIA (CAP-MALARIA) - MALARIA
long_description: The Control and Prevention of Malaria (CAP-Malaria) project will advance the efforts of Cambodia's National Malaria Program to strengthen malaria prevention and control in the border areas of Cambodia where there is drug resistant malaria. The CAP-Malaria project will conduct behavior-change communication campaigns to increase awareness about malaria prevention, particularly among mobile and migrant workers. It will distribute approximately 50,000 insecticide-treated bed nets to vulnerable populations. CAP-Malaria will strengthen antenatal care practices among health workers in high prevalence areas to improve care for patients and the use of rapid diagnostic tests. The project will also track malaria-borne mosquitos and their biting behaviors and facilitate cross-border cooperation between Thai and Cambodian health authorities. This effort will reduce Cambodia's malaria burden, including malaria-related deaths, as well as move Cambodia towards the pre-elimination stage of malaria in specific areas.

title: Control and Prevention of Malaria (CAP-Malaria) - Malaria
short_description: CONTROL AND PREVENTION OF MALARIA (CAP-MALARIA) - MALARIA
long_description: The Control and Prevention of Malaria (CAP-Malaria) project will advance the efforts of Cambodias National Malaria Program to strengthen malaria prevention and control in the border areas of Cambodia where there is drug resistant malaria. The CAP-Malaria project will conduct behavior-change communication campaigns to increase awareness about malaria prevention, particularly among mobile and migrant workers. It will distribute approximately 50,000 insecticide-treated bed nets to vulnerable populations. CAP-Malaria will strengthen antenatal care practices among health workers in high prevalence areas to improve care for patients and the use of rapid diagnostic tests. The project will also track malaria-borne mosquitos and their biting behaviors and facilitate cross-border cooperation between Thai and Cambodian health authorities. This effort will reduce Cambodias malaria burden, including malaria-related deaths, as well as move Cambodia towards the pre-elimination stage of malaria in specific areas.

title: Counter Trafficking in Persons II (CTIP II) - Human Rights
short_description: COUNTER TRAFFICKING IN PERSONS II (CTIP II) - HUMAN RIGHTS
long_description: The program approach to counter trafficking in persons includes interventions focused on protection of victims, prosecution of perpetrators, prevention of trafficking, and improving the national policy and coordination function of the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC). By doing so, it adds an additional element of policy coordination to the well-accepted formula of the  3 P s  of prevention, prosecution and protection. The goal of the program is to improve the ability of Cambodian institutions to combat trafficking in persons.

long_description: The purpose of this project is to identify Asian elephant hotspots within the south-eastern Cardamom Mountains Landscape to inform future monitoring programs and management response, and support communities to mitigate human-elephant conflict (HEC). Grantee will, 1) Conduct fecal concentration surveys within the eastern and southern Cardamom Mountains Landscape to identify elephant hotspots, by end 2014; 2) Reduce human-elephant conflict through strengthening local management of human-elephant conflict at key sites.

title: Development for All strategy: Partner Country Support
short_description: DEVELOPMENT FOR ALL STRATEGY: PARTNER COUNTRY SUPPORT
long_description: The Development for All strategy, developed in close consultation with people with disability and their representative organisations, is the first strategy to guide Australia's overseas aid program towards development that includes people with disability. The strategy reflects the Government's commitment to social inclusion, progress towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and is framed in the context of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities to which Australia is party. The primary outcome of the strategy is improved quality of life for people with disability and including people with disability across all aspects of the Australian aid program. Other outcomes include reduced preventable impairments, effective leadership on disability and development, AusAID skilled and confident in disability-inclusive development, and improved understanding of disability and development. From 2008-09 to 2009-10 this initiative funded early planning and implementation of the Development for All Strategy.  From 2010-11, this initiative will comprise both budget measure and base program funding for further planning, implementation and monitoring of Development for All. The total value of this multi-country initiative is $99.0 million over 8 years, starting 2008-09.

title: Development of Self-sustaining Education Programs for Prospective Eye Health Professionals in Cambodia
short_description: DEVELOPMENT OF SELF-SUSTAINING EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOR PROSPECTIVE EYE HEALTH PROFESSIONALS IN CAMBODIA
long_description: About 6.137 of the population (520 thousand people) in Cambodia suffers from serious visual impairment and is living with vision impairment that may create socioeconomic barriers. To overcome, the Cambodian government has carried out a visual health policy since 1995. However, it focused mostly on facility construction such as eye hospitals and lacked educational programs to train eye health professionals. More than 4237 of the visually impaired people can be improved without surgery. At present, educational programs are needed to train eye health professionals in Cambodia.

The goal   of the programme is to deepend democratic participation among         grassroots to facilitate a strong local development, leading to a     reduction of poverty, increased self-determination and better         material and emotional standards of living.

title: Diakonia Human Rights and Democracy Program in    Cambodia, 2014-2016 - Diakonia Democracy and Human Rights 2014-2016
short_description: DIAKONIA HUMAN RIGHTS AND DEMOCRACY PROGRAM IN    CAMBODIA, 2014-2016 - DIAKONIA DEMOCRACY AND HUMAN RIGHTS 2014-2016
long_description: Support to local human rights organisations doing monitoring and      reporting of human rights in Cambodia.

title: Diakonia Human Rights and Democracy Program in Cambodia, 2014-2016 - Diakonia Democracy and Human Rights 2014-2016
short_description: DIAKONIA HUMAN RIGHTS AND DEMOCRACY PROGRAM IN CAMBODIA, 2014-2016 - DIAKONIA DEMOCRACY AND HUMAN RIGHTS 2014-2016
long_description: The Diakonia  Human Rights and Democracy Programme in Cambodia  is based on a five-year-perspective. However, the funding request is based on a three-year-period only, in line with previous discussions between the Embassy and Diakonia to this effect. The total budget for the period 2014-2016 amounts to SEK 36 000 000.The main objective of the programme is to support the growth of a pluralistic and independent civil society that is enabled to promote good governance and democratic participation. The intervention is designed to promote active citizenship through a human rights based approach and a strategy of change that stresses awareness raising, organizing and collective action and advocacy as means to enable the right holders to actively participate in the planning and implementation of initiatives that benefit them and improve their access to rights.To this end, Diakonia will continue to provide financial support (mainly in the form of core-funding) and capacity building to a number of local partner organisations (for 2014, the number is 13). In line with the strategy of change, Diakonia will support the development away from a civil society dominated by professional NGOs and top-down service delivery organisations towards a more pluralistic, more empowering, more representative, more independent, less elitist, more gender equal and more democratically organized civil society.The intervention is built around three broad results areas: 1) Democracy; 2) Gender equality; and 3) Human Rights. Promoting democratic values and defending democratic freedoms where they are at risk constitute key principles of the intervention. Actions relating to freedom of assembly, association and expression are particularly pronounced, along with other initiatives trying to counteract infringements of democratic rights. ICT technology is recognized as a key tool for communication, evidence-based advocacy and data collection as well as a means to organise and form associations.The proposed form of Swedish financing is through a grant, which is deemed appropriate for the type of capacity development support that Diakonia is providing. The intervention will be implemented as a project since there are no programme-based alternatives. Diakonia will channel part of the funds to third parties (i.e. local CSOs). Sweden is currently the only donor. Coordination among donors and other stakeholders however remains relevant in order to share information, good practices and lessons learned and to avoid overlapping activities.

title: Diakonia secure reporting ICT - Diakonia secure reporting
short_description: DIAKONIA SECURE REPORTING ICT - DIAKONIA SECURE REPORTING
long_description: Diakonia has submitted a request to the Embassy for a one-year-extension of the ongoing project Human Rights in the Cyber Age: Safeguarding the message and the messenger (UF2012/68825 PHNO, PLUS ID 51100023), also referred to as the ICT project. In the extension proposal, Diakonia concludes that ICT has proved to be a valuable resource for human rights defenders in Cambodia, and that the four partner organisations in the ICT-project are now integrating ICT into all their core awareness raising activities, civil society mobilizing and evidence based advocacy. New ICT-tools are also being used for cost-effective and safe internal communication.Diakonia also concludes that while the foundations have been established during the two-year-project period, continued efforts are needed to build capacity, increase the pool of activists and audience reach, and explore new ICT tools that can be used in the human rights defense and promotion work. The extension period will be used to consolidate the collaborative work between Diakonia and its current four partners. The partners include three human rights organisations; Community Legal Education Center (CLEC), Cambodian League for Promotion and Defense of Human Rights (LICADHO) and Samakum Theang Tnaot (STT) and one media organization; Cambodian Centre for Independent Media (CCIM). It is expected that the continued support will contribute to make some of the key human rights organisations more efficient and effective in their work. It is also expected to create an environment for more accurate and stringent information collection and transmission. The support provided for the extension period amounts to SEK 2.5 million, which makes the total Swedish financial support to this contribution amount to SEK 9.2 million covering the period from January 2013 to December 2015.

title: Direct protection to Asia's last intact elephant corridor, Cambodia
short_description: DIRECT PROTECTION TO ASIA'S LAST INTACT ELEPHANT CORRIDOR, CAMBODIA
long_description: The Southern Cardamom Forest Protection Program (SCFPP) implements a direct, holistic approach to forest protection in Cambodia, providing ranger patrols which protect wild Asian elephants and their habitats from poaching and land encroachment in this landscape. This project will protect Asian elephants by improving ranger effectiveness through training, strengthen good governance by building strong cases and following-up with the courts on active cases; provide investigative skill development training; and create better linkages between remote villages and ranger stations to address land encroachment. SCFPP rangers will conduct daily forest patrols to effectively resolve human-elephant conflicts, operate ranger stations, and preserve the forests of the Southern Cardamom Mountains of Cambodia.

title: Disability Rights Initiative Cambodia
short_description: DISABILITY RIGHTS INITIATIVE CAMBODIA
long_description: The Disability Rights Initiative Cambodia (DRIC) is a joint United Nations Ì± Australian Aid Program to improve quality of life for people with disability.  The program has four components: 1)- Supporting Government implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities; 2)- Supporting Disabled People's Organisations to raise the voice and protect the rights of people with disability; 3)- Supporting rehabilitation systems strengthening; and 4)- Inclusive governance and inclusive community development. The program is implemented by three UN agencies Ì± UNDP, WHO and UNICEF, with a coordination unit to support overall management of the program.  The Australian Government has an agreement with the UNDP Multi-Partner Trust Fund Office to coordinate these UN bodies in implementing the program. The agreed total value of Australia's contribution is $10.4 million over 4 years, starting 2013-14.

title: Disability Rights Initiative Cambodia
short_description: DISABILITY RIGHTS INITIATIVE CAMBODIA
long_description: The Disability Rights Initiative Cambodia (DRIC) is a joint United Nations Ì± Australian Aid Program to improve quality of life for people with disability.  The program has four components: MoSVY/DAC effectively coordinates implementation of the National Disability Strategic Plan, aligned to the CRPD; disabled People's Organisations effectively represent the needs and priorities and advocate for the rights of people with disability; improved rehabilitation services for people with disability; and increased capacity of and collaboration between subnational decision makers, civil society and communities to achieve the rights of people with disability. The program is implemented by three UN agencies Ì± UNDP, WHO and UNICEF, with a coordination unit to support overall management of the program.  The Australian Government has an agreement with the UNDP Multi-Partner Trust Fund Office to coordinate these UN bodies in implementing the program. The total value of Australia's contribution is $13.2 million over 5 years, starting 2013-14.

title: Diversification of Lowland Cropping Systems in Laos and Cambodia
short_description: DIVERSIFICATION OF LOWLAND CROPPING SYSTEMS IN LAOS AND CAMBODIA
long_description: Cambodia and Laos share problems of widespread rural poverty, food insecurity, and malnutrition. Rainfed lowland rice, grown once a year in the wet season, is the backbone of agricultural production, but is largely subsistence-oriented with low productivity. Household income would be increased and rural poverty reduced if quality rice and non-rice crops could be successfully grown. The aim of this project is to identify mechanisation options and post-harvest technologies to enhance household livelihoods and food security in lowland rice-growing areas. This will be achieved by utilising a systems approach, integrating mechanised cropping practices, including combine harvesting, and post-harvest practices, in particular artificial dryers, that together increase the intensification, potential for diversification, the labour efficiency of the cropping system and the market value of the produce.

title: East Asia Avoidable Blindness
short_description: EAST ASIA AVOIDABLE BLINDNESS
long_description: The East Asia Avoidable Blindness Initiative is aimed at reducing avoidable blindness and improving the quality of life for people with low vision and blindness, in support of the Vision 2020 'Right to Sight' global initiative. It will scale up and improve the delivery, availability and utilisation of eye health and vision care services and support better integration of eye health services in to national health systems. The East Asia Avoidable Blindness Initiative is built around three program components: a joint World Health Organisation (WHO) and International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) regional work plan providing technical and policy support to the Western Pacific region; country program support in Cambodia, Vietnam and Timor-Leste implemented through Vision 2020 Australia Global Consortium; and direct bilateral support to the national eye institutions of partner governments in Cambodia and Vietnam to strengthen eye health systems.  The total value of this initiative is $11.5 million over 3 years, starting 2012-13.

title: Education Quality Improvement Project
short_description: EDUCATION QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECT
long_description: Education Quality Improvement Project

title: Education Quality Improvement Project
short_description: EDUCATION QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECT
long_description: The Education Quality Improvement Project for Cambodia aims to develop a demonstration model, shown to be effective for extension to other provinces, of a participatory approach to school quality improvement and performance-based resource management. The project has two main components. The first component finances a quality improvement grants program that 1) recruits and trains  animators  (or  lightning rods ) who work with community and school cluster leaders to engage them in discussions about effective schools, in identifying problems and solutions, and in developing cluster improvement plans as a basis for preparing grant proposals; 2) supports a provincial grants management committee which meets annually to review proposals; 3) provides quality improvement grants to school clusters; 4) and supplies training, monitoring, and evaluation funds for activities related to the professional development of animators as well as assisting in monitoring and evaluating grants by other officials. The second component supports the institutional strengthening/capacity building of Cambodia's education sector by supporting the National Committee on Effective Schooling; funding policy studies, including grade four examinations and decentralization); and providing operational support for provincial and district education offices.

title: Education Sector Development Program
short_description: EDUCATION SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM
long_description: The overall objective of the Education Sector Development Program (ESDP) is to contribute to Cambodia's broader  poverty reduction policy by assisting the Government in reforming and strengthening the education sector as outlined i n the Government's Education Strategic Plan (ESP). The ESDP will support nationwide policy reforms related to education finance, removal of access barriers to education for poor students, improved learning, more efficient and transparent education service delivery, and decentralized management, and provide investment funds to support the implementation of policies designed to improve equitable access to quality education for under-served and disadvantaged populations..

short_description: EDUCATION SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

The Project will provide construction of facilities in remote and underserved areas, promote greater deconcentration of the planning of facilities programs to provincial authorities and institutions, and pilot budget management of facilities development in four provinces.

title: Elephant conservation & capacity building in Seima Protection Forest, Cambodia - Year 8
short_description: ELEPHANT CONSERVATION & CAPACITY BUILDING IN SEIMA PROTECTION FOREST, CAMBODIA - YEAR 8
long_description: The purpose of this project is to sustain and improve conservation of Asian elephants and build capacity of rangers and community patrols in Seima Protection Forest. Project activities will include: 1) implement anti-poaching patrols and monitoring of elephant habitat; 2) monitor forest loss and encroachment using remote sensing and Geographic Information Systems; 3) establish community patrol teams in one new village; 4) increase capacity of new and existing community patrols through training and equipment; 5) establish a reporting network for human-elephant conflict; 6) conduct extensive training for field teams on survey methods and protocols; and 7) conduct the HEC survey in parallel with the elephant DNA survey. This project will contribute to a well-managed forest landscape that supports increasing wildlife populations and improved livelihoods for the communities of the Seima Protection Forest.

title: Elephant Conservation And Capacity-Building In Seima Protection Forest, Cambodia: Year 7
short_description: ELEPHANT CONSERVATION AND CAPACITY-BUILDING IN SEIMA PROTECTION FOREST, CAMBODIA: YEAR 7
long_description: The purpose of this project is to, (1) increase the intensity of field monitoring by law enforcement staff in and around elephant hotspots, (2) improve capacity to monitor existing forest encroachment, and inform the project in real-time of emerging threats, using advanced technologies, and adapt management strategies accordingly, and (3) establish a community-based patrolling system for monitoring remote parts of the project area that are under threat from deforestation, but one that ranger patrols are able to access only infrequently.

title: Empowering Communities for Health (ECH) project - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
short_description: EMPOWERING COMMUNITIES FOR HEALTH (ECH) PROJECT - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
long_description: The ECH mechanism is working to build the capacity of CCs to manage and support the health system functions delegated to communities. ECH supports community agents to promote appropriate home health and nutrition behaviors, optimal health care-seeking, and improving community-based provision of .tuberculosis (TB) treatment and contraceptive services. Additionally, it is working to improve community awareness of the rights of health care consumers (as set forth in the MOHs Client Rights Charter),   strengthen social accountability and assist CCs to fully exert the health care stewardship role envisioned for them in the MOHs Guidelines for Operational Districts.

title: Empowering women through humane workplaces: Garment factories in Southeast Asia
short_description: EMPOWERING WOMEN THROUGH HUMANE WORKPLACES: GARMENT FACTORIES IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
long_description: In Asia, garment factories play a dominant role in the employment opportunities for women, yet these factories have some of the harshest working conditions in the region. Across Asian factories, new management improvements are being tested to advance working conditions and comply with international labour conventions while enhancing productivity and competitiveness. These include training of managers, promotion of work-life balance, and incentive pay. In Vietnam and Indonesia, the ministries of labour have engaged with the international community to implement these programs. New trade agreements such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership are also opening opportunities for workers and policymakers to support such interventions. There is growing understanding that when factories treat workers fairlyÌ_especially womenÌ_they show greater psychological empowerment to advocate change, while workers who experience verbal and physical abuse by supervisors feel disempowered, their mindset suffers, and they become less productive at work. This research project aims to improve the understanding of the link between working conditions, well-being, and productivity. The project will compare female factory workers that participate in a program with better working conditions with those who do not. It will examine whether compliance with better working conditions affects mindsets, and how in turn this impacts work performance and workers' well-being. It will also assess the development impact of improvement in job quality among young female workers, and what interventions can best address the current conditions of working women in the garment industry.The project will be implemented by a multi-disciplinary team of researchers from the industrial psychology, management science, and economic sectors. They will engage directly with stakeholders in ministries of labour and garment factory associations. The University of Indonesia will involve the working group on decent work within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), which tackles labour policies at the regional level. The project will promote collaboration and capacity building of local research teams in Indonesia and Vietnam and will disseminate findings widely to the scholarly, policy, industry, and private sector communities through working papers and briefs as well as targeted public events.

title: Ending Violence Against Women - Program Design
short_description: ENDING VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN - PROGRAM DESIGN
long_description: Ending violence against women and girls at home, in their communities and in disaster and conflict situations is one of the four pillars of Australia's gender equality strategy. This strategy highlights that a more strategic and targeted focus is needed in areas where progress has been slow and that the highest levels of expenditure will be in the countries with the most severe gender gaps. Cambodia meets this criterion as it ranks 99 out of 145 countries in the Gender Inequality Index (GII) of the 2011 Human Development Report (HDR), which is one of the lowest rankings in the region. The program will work with the Ministry of Women's Affairs (MOWA) of the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC), the Ministries of Interior and Justice (through CCJAP) and Cambodian Civil Society to deliver a comprehensive response to VAW. In the short term, we will: support the development of a new National Action Plan on Violence Against Women (NAPVAW) that is fully costed, evidence based, and developed in consultation with communities, survivors of violence, Civil Society Organisations (CSO) and whole of government, to identify a comprehensive and coordinated  response to VAW; and b) support a prevalence study that will ensure resources are well targeted need. In the medium term (July-December) the program will undertake a joint design with UN Women to: 1) identify the best modality for civil society support for providing victim assistance services, legal aid,  advocacy and community awareness/behaviour change; and 2) assess the feasibility of integrating the legal enforcement aspects of the NAPVAW into the new phase of assistance to the justice sector); andlonger term we will have: i) an Agreement with UN Women to manage a civil society program window; and  ii) integrated feasible components of NAPVAW into the 2013 CCJAP Annual Plans, leveraging additional funding to make real improvements. The total value of this initiative is $3.6 million over 4 years, starting 2011-12.

In the medium term (July-December) the program will undertake a joint design with UN Women to: 1) identify the best modality for civil society support for providing victim assistance services, legal aid,  advocacy and community awareness/behaviour change; and 2) assess the feasibility of integrating the legal enforcement aspects of the NAPVAW into the new phase of assistance to the justice sector); and longer term we will have: i) an Agreement with UN Women to manage a civil society program window; and  ii) integrated feasible components of NAPVAW into the 2013 CCJAP Annual Plans, leveraging additional funding to make real improvements. The total value of this initiative is $15.7million over 5 years, starting 2011-12.

title: Ending Violence Against Women in Cambodia
short_description: ENDING VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN IN CAMBODIA
long_description: Ending violence against women and girls at home, in their communities and in disaster and conflict situations is one of the four pillars of Australia's gender equality strategy. This strategy highlights that a more strategic and targeted focus is needed in areas where progress has been slow and that the highest levels of expenditure will be in the countries with the most severe gender gaps. Cambodia meets this criterion as it ranks 99 out of 145 countries in the Gender Inequality Index (GII) of the 2011 Human Development Report (HDR), which is one of the lowest rankings in the region. The program will work with the Ministry of Women's Affairs (MOWA) of the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC), the Ministries of Interior and Justice (through CCJAP) and Cambodian Civil Society to deliver a comprehensive response to VAW. The total value of this initiative is $15.7million over 5 years, starting 2011-12.

title: Engineers Without Borders: Core Funding
short_description: ENGINEERS WITHOUT BORDERS: CORE FUNDING
long_description: The Australia - Non-Government Organisations (NGO) Cooperation Program (ANCP) subsidises the poverty reduction activities of accredited Australian NGOs.  Australian NGOs supported through ANCP must demonstrate a strong level of Australian community support, and have been through a rigorous accreditation process.  The total value of this multi-country program is $627.4 million over 4 years, starting 2013-14.

title: Enhanced Conservation of Yellow-Cheeked Crested Gibbon Through Targeted Habitat Protection and Ecotourism Development in Southern Mondulkiri, Cambodia
short_description: ENHANCED CONSERVATION OF YELLOW-CHEEKED CRESTED GIBBON THROUGH TARGETED HABITAT PROTECTION AND ECOTOURISM DEVELOPMENT IN SOUTHERN MONDULKIRI, CAMBODIA
long_description: The purpose of this project is to continue to protect gibbons and critical gibbon habitat through direct law enforcement, and support the continuing development of gibbon-based ecotourism through targeted law enforcement, further capacity building, and project monitoring.

long_description: The purpose of this project is to continue to protect gibbons and critical gibbon habitat through direct law enforcement, and support the continuing development of gibbon-based ecotourism through targeted law enforcement, further capacity building, and project monitoring.

title: Enhanced Protection and Habitat Conservation for At-Risk Ape Populations in Cambodia
short_description: ENHANCED PROTECTION AND HABITAT CONSERVATION FOR AT-RISK APE POPULATIONS IN CAMBODIA
long_description: The purpose of this project is to establish a long-term protection mechanism and serve as a model for enhancing protection of critical wildlife sites in NE India where situations are dire and manpower is short. The project will accomplish the following objectives and associated activities: (1) Continue the operations of the two roving gibbon and wildlife patrol units comprising of 3 community members and headed by a forest guard. A new group will also be introduced this year resulting in a total of 3 groups. (2) Implement SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrolling protocols; systematically record patrol details and produce monthly reports; plan future patrols using these reports. FWS support will provide the salaries of 8 guards and honorariums for 3 forest staff for 12 months. There will be special training of the guards on wildlife conservation, how to combat poaching, and SMART patrolling.

title: Establishing Gibbon Monitoring In Bokor National Park Through Supporting Cambodia's Future..Conservation Professionals
short_description: ESTABLISHING GIBBON MONITORING IN BOKOR NATIONAL PARK THROUGH SUPPORTING CAMBODIA'S FUTURE..CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS
long_description: The purpose of this proposal is to initiate a pileated gibbon monitoring program by conducting repeat surveys at 10 sites in Bokur NP. This will be done by: 1) developing a pileated gibbon monitoring protocol for Bokor NP; 2) identifying areas of high gibbon density within Bokor NP and their preferred habitat; 3) determining the feasibility of undertaking a joint approach to long term gibbon monitoring and conservation in the park with the park's major concession holder Thansur Bokor Mountain Resort and the national park's management; and 4) improving national capacity to undertake gibbon conservation.

title: Evaluation of Civil Society Strategy - Program Design and Learning
short_description: EVALUATION OF CIVIL SOCIETY STRATEGY - PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING
long_description: Social Impact was awarded a contract to conduct an updated evaluation of current USAID/Cambodia programs in order to assess the performance of the programs with respect to providing support to civil society and indigenous NGOs involved in the promotion and protection of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. USAID will use this evaluation as a basis for program improvement in light of the enhanced focus that will be placed on civil society in the coming years.

title: Evaluation of the Counter-Trafficking in Persons Program (CTIP) - Program Design and Learning
short_description: EVALUATION OF THE COUNTER-TRAFFICKING IN PERSONS PROGRAM (CTIP) - PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING
long_description: The project was to evaluate the CTIP program to determine if it is successful in improving coordination and collection of data between anti-trafficking actors; enhancing victim care through development and implementation of national standards; and improving access to justice for victims of trafficking, both directly and indirectly.

title: EVIDENCE Project Cambodia - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
short_description: EVIDENCE PROJECT CAMBODIA - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
long_description: The Workplace Wellness Program Global Development Alliance will leverage private-sector resources to improve the reproductive health and nutritional status of young women in the garment industry. The U.S. government will leverage funding and in-kind support from the private sector, including major international clothing companies, to improve garment workers knowledge about their health-care rights and health needs. This project will also increase factory workers access to quality healthcare. U.S. government diplomatic and democracy and governance activities will complement this project by improving labor relations and labor rights by leveraging the influence of international clothing companies.

title: EVIDENCE Project Cambodia - Family Planning and Reproductive Health
short_description: EVIDENCE PROJECT CAMBODIA - FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH
long_description: The Workplace Wellness Program Global Development Alliance will leverage private-sector resources to improve the reproductive health and nutritional status of young women in the garment industry. The U.S. government will leverage funding and in-kind support from the private sector, including major international clothing companies, to improve garment workers' knowledge about their health-care rights and health needs. This project will also increase factory workers' access to quality healthcare. U.S. government diplomatic and democracy and governance activities will complement this project by improving labor relations and labor rights by leveraging the influence of international clothing companies.

title: EVIDENCE Project Cambodia - Maternal and Child Health
short_description: EVIDENCE PROJECT CAMBODIA - MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH
long_description: The Workplace Wellness Program Global Development Alliance will leverage private-sector resources to improve the reproductive health and nutritional status of young women in the garment industry. The U.S. government will leverage funding and in-kind support from the private sector, including major international clothing companies, to improve garment workers knowledge about their health-care rights and health needs. This project will also increase factory workers access to quality healthcare. U.S. government diplomatic and democracy and governance activities will complement this project by improving labor relations and labor rights by leveraging the influence of international clothing companies.

title: F.a: Cambodia Changemaker Network (CCN)
short_description: F.A: CAMBODIA CHANGEMAKER NETWORK (CCN)
long_description: In Cambodia 65 % of the population is under age of 30 and therefore youth empowerment is an imperative. While youth is dynamic resource, there is little representation of young people in decision-making process. Robust youth participation is perhaps the strongest mechanism to enable their potential contribute to the development of their community. By building capacity among Cambodian youth, Cambodia Changemaker Network (CNN) is empowering the next generation of leaders and agents of change.Objectives:Ìø To enhance space and opportunities for youth to be actively involved in the society and policy making process Ìø To increase knowledge, skills and awareness of youth on human rights, education and peaceExpected Result: Ìø Youth have enhanced knowledge and capacity to constructively engage in advocacy actionsÌø Youth have increased opportunity and spaces to express their voices on their concerned issuesÌø Strengthened youth organisation and networkingRights-holders/beneficiaries:Cambodia Changemaker Network has identified the core to establish the network in 2014. During 2015 this group has been growing to more than 100 members with diverse background including high school students, university students, monks, disabled, and staff from different NGOs and public sector. Many of them are from Phnom Penh city, and some smaller numbers are from provinces including Kom Pong Spue, Bonteay Meanchey, Kompong Cham, Siem Reap, Battam Bong, Kandal, and Prey Veng. Implementing partner: Khmer Youth Association (KYA) was a hosting partner for Cambodia Changemaker Network (CNN) in 2015, but for 2016 CNN members have agreed to have FCA as the hosting partner. FCA is able to provide effective administration and other technical support to the network as needed.
