title: F.a: Chab Dai- assisting victims of human trafficking
short_description: F.A: CHAB DAI- ASSISTING VICTIMS OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING
long_description: Cambodia is a country of both origin and transit for human trafficking. The relations and trust between the police and communities has historically been weak and not serving the best interest of victims. The project builds the capacity of duty bearers (police and authorities, government and other stakeholders) in providing protection and access to justice to the child victims of human trafficking and abuse. A training curriculum will be designed based on a study of the authorities' knowledge and skills regarding child rights. Training material will be made to address the real needs of the authorities working directly with victims and their families. The training will cover the psycho-social aspects of the work with child victims, as well as appropriate legal procedures and law. Project will also facilitate trainings on Child Rights in communities, including local police and authorities in order to build better relations and trust between the police and communities. The expected results of the project are improved understanding and strengthened practices of child rights, children are protected better from exploitation and victims and their families are protected and have access to justice. A connected network will be formed to facilitate a timely and coordinated child victim care and child protection. Direct beneficiaries are 60 local Police in Prey Veng and Svay Rieng, 210 local community people, community and church leaders. Final beneficiaries are children who are in danger of exploitation and human trafficking. The implementing partner is Chab Dai Coalition.

title: F.a: Chab Dai- assisting victims of human trafficking
short_description: F.A: CHAB DAI- ASSISTING VICTIMS OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING
long_description: WHAT: Education for social workers and therapists as well as direct crisis support for the victims is organized. Training for social workers and staff of other NGOs.  WHY: Cambodia is the country of both origin and transit for human trafficking, and the number of sex offences has increased in recent years. The project aims to provide the victims with quality crisis support, social support and protection. RESULTS: The victims will have immediate access to direct crisis support. Social workers and therapists are able to provide relevant psychosocial support. They are familiar with the child welfare policies and their own well-being is supported. Chab Dai member organizations' knowledge on child protection is increased. BENEFICIARIES: victims of trafficking and sexual abuse, social workers, other NGOs. PARTNER: Chab Dai

title: F.a: Community Health Education Programme
short_description: F.A: COMMUNITY HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAMME
long_description: Community Health Education Programme. The programme aims to empower a local partner for independent community development work. Fida's partner in Cambodia is Cambodia Global Action (CGA), an NGO owned by the Assemblies of God church of Cambodia (AOG). Fida and CGA work together in the local communities, which provide the partner with hands-on training in community development. The main approach used is that of Community Health Education (CHE). The programme has expanded to over 70 villages and will soon cover up to 130 villages altogether. Through the programme, the partner's capacities in community development grow and the organization will be able to carry out community development projects independently. In addition, CGA will be able to multiply the effect through training local churches on CHE. As a result communities all over Cambodia will be holistically changed.

title: F.a: Community Health Education Programme
short_description: F.A: COMMUNITY HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAMME
long_description: There is a tremendous need for basic education on health and livelihood issues in the project area. The project targets rural communities through trainings and basic education.‰ÛÊ For 2016, the focus is on climate change risk reduction and adaptation. The project will select one or two active families per village in the target area to demonstrate as model families. The project will also motivate key people, such as local authorities and pastors, to establish gender committees in each village to promote gender balance. There will also be trainings on child protection issues and human trafficking. Fida partners with Cambodia Global Action, a local NGO, in the project. The project's goal is holistically changed target communities in Cambodia. The purpose is empowered partner to implement community development work through implementation and training of community health education. The project results in increased basic education and improved living standards, improved structure and governance of the communities, improved health of the children, improvement of children's rights, reduced domestic violence, increased gender equality, and increased awareness on climate change and disaster preparedness of the project beneficiaries. The beneficiaries include women, men, children, and vulnerable groups in the target communities, village development committee and community health education volunteers.

title: F.a: Community-based support for children with disabilities
short_description: F.A: COMMUNITY-BASED SUPPORT FOR CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES
long_description: The project enhances the rights of children with severe disabilities by training communities and their leaders on disability issues and the rights of persons with disabilities, by supporting community based day centres and schools as well as home based care, in Kampot and Kratie provinces. Children with disabilities in Cambodia and their families often live in poverty. Only 3% of disabled children start school and more than half of them drop out soon. Countryside is almost totally lacking educational and supporting services for severely disabled children and ignorance and discriminating attitudes cause enormous barriers to their wellbeing. Without the support of community, parents and authorities the children don't have possibility to develop their skills physically, socially or educationally. However, the work of the project implementer Komar Pikar Foundation (KPF) has proved that by community based solutions even the severely disabled children and their families can have access to education and supporting services and the discrimination can be reduced. As result of the project the children with severe disabilities are accepted as part of their communities, they have possibility to learn and develop their skills and have better access to e.g. health services. The financial status of the families improves and discrimination is reduced.

title: F.a: Community-based support for children with disabilities
short_description: F.A: COMMUNITY-BASED SUPPORT FOR CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES
long_description: WHAT: Improving the status of seriously disabled children by education about human rights, supporting community-based day school activities and establishing rehabilitation groups.WHY: Cambodian seriously disabled children and their families are often without adequate livelihood, education and support services. The project aims in ensuring that these rights actualize. RESULTS: Seriously disabled children will be able to participate in community-based activities, their families will have both financial and social capacities to support them and discrimination against them will decrease. Children with severe disabilities and their families in Cambodian rural communities. KUMPPANI: Komar Pikar Foundation (KPF)

title: F.a: Cooperation for Women's Economic Development (CWED)
short_description: F.A: COOPERATION FOR WOMEN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (CWED)
long_description: The Women's Economic Development (CWED) project is aiming at women's empowerment, economic development, and building their confidence to make decisions. The CWED project is a follow-up for the 4-year project Women: Hope and Growth that established 24 Women's Agriculture Cooperatives (WAC) and built their capacity on governance, leadership and management, as well as technical skills of bookkeeping and business management. The project will promote entrepreneurship, continue to support vulnerable women to play an active role to lead and manage Agriculture Cooperatives and establish market linkages through value chain concepts. The project continues to build WACs capacity, while further strengthening the coordination with various stakeholders for additional support and market linkages. The selection of the 12 WACs was done in late 2014, based on their potential to growth according to the result of the final evaluation of the WHG project and capacity assessment conducted after the completion of the project. The excepted results are:Ìø Improved business capacity of women leaders in micro and small business group through provision of capacity building and mentoring on business plan to WAC management committee and small business groups and setting up the operational model for micro and small business groups.Ìø Strengthen business networking of WACs and business actors and duty-bearersÌø Improve project staff capacity in providing business mentoring; Training course on the business and value chain based on the capacity assessment aimed at passing on this knowledge and related skills to WACs.Rights-holders /beneficiaries: At least 2,331 direct beneficiaries who are the members of 12 WAC's in 4 provinces will benefit from this project. Indirect beneficiaries are the families of the WAC members and community residents. At least 80% of the direct beneficiaries are women.Implementing partner: Life with Dignity (LWD) is FCA's long-term in Cambodia. LWD has good experience in implementing livelihood projects through rights based empowerment approach. The participation and community mobilisation experiences are the strengths of LWD.Technical or specialised institutes, especially on business sector, will be hired to conduct a series of capacity building and mentoring to agricultural cooperatives to ensure that the business plan and operation are smoothly applied and benefit AC members, particularly smallholders.

title: F.a: Coordination of Development Cooperation
short_description: F.A: COORDINATION OF DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION
long_description: FELM's development coordinator enhances the local partners' capacity to cope with the requirements of development cooperation. The work includes monitoring of the ongoing work and its compatibility with FELM strategy, capasity building activities for partner organisations, identification of new partners and following the local context. As result the partners have incresed capasity to cope with the project management requirements and thematic issues and FELM has up-to date- information about the progress of the work. Beneficiaries are the partner organisations and FELM's own organisation and its workers.

title: F.a: Coordination of Development Cooperation
short_description: F.A: COORDINATION OF DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION
long_description: WHAT: monitoring and evaluation of the ingoing work and its compatibility with FELM strategy. Capasity building activities for partner organisations. Identification of new partners and following the local context WHY: There is a need for resource person(s) to enhance the capasity of partners to cope with the requirements of development cooperation. RESULTS: Incresed capasity of partners to cope with the project management requirements and thematic issues. FELM has up-to date- information about the progress of the work. BENEFICIARIES: Partner organisation, FELM s own organisation and its workers

title: F.a: Deaf Empowerment and Awareness in Cambodia
short_description: F.A: DEAF EMPOWERMENT AND AWARENESS IN CAMBODIA
long_description: FAD: Deaf Empowerment and Awareness in Cambodia (DEA). WHAT: The project locates young deaf people who previously haven't gotten chance to educate or support themselves, and provides them access to education, livelihood and the Deaf community.WHY: 97 % of the deaf in Cambodia have never learned any language, gotten to school or met another deaf person. The deaf in Cambodia are usually dependent on their family and they live on the edge of family life and the society.HOW: By supporting deaf education, sign language and the Deaf community together with raising deaf awareness in the society, the Deaf community is able to advocate for equal human rights for the Deaf and sign language users. The project benefits the deaf entering civil society for the first time and their relatives.PARTNER ORGANISATION: The project is implemented together with Maryknoll Cambodia which is an American organization under which the Deaf Development Programme has operated since 2002.

title: F.a: Empowering youth in orphanages
short_description: F.A: EMPOWERING YOUTH IN ORPHANAGES
long_description: Cambodia has more than 140 registered orphanages and countless unregistered residential care centres. Only a quarter of children living in these institutions have lost their both parents. In most cases the reason for sending a child to an orphanage is poverty and the common belief that an orphanage would provide a better future. In reality insecurity, poor governance, violence and indifference are common in orphanages, and the young people are not supported to develop life skills and social abilities. After leaving the orphanage they are likely to face unemployment, drugs, gangs, crime and sexual exploitation. They are also easy victims of human trafficking. The project implementing partner M'lup Russey promotes alternative, community based choices for residential care. It seeks to influence the decision makers, managers of orphanages and other stakeholders to take responsibility of monitoring and development of the child protection standards. It creates alternative working models to the orphanages and strengthens young people's life skills. M'lup Russey is one of the main partners of the Cambodian Ministry of Social Affairs in implementing child protection policies. Project activities include development of community-based child protection models, orphanage staff training in child protection issues and supporting young people's independence, youth clubs in orphanages, support for vocational training and assistance in finding work placements, training for mentors and village-level networks, group activities to promote young people's social skills and life skills, as well as preparatory meetings for family reunification.

title: F.a: Empowering youth in orphanages
short_description: F.A: EMPOWERING YOUTH IN ORPHANAGES
long_description: WHAT: Work against abuse of children and youth by developing child welfare, establishing youth clubs, supporting vocational education, training mentors, improving the coping skills of the young as well as establishing supportive networks. Training for authorities, child welfare workers and other NGOs. WHY: Many deprived families in Cambodia send their children to live in orphanages in order to provide a better future for their children. However, many of the orphanages don't meet even the minimum standards of child protection. Necklet, abuse and lack of life skills and support network are the reality of many children and youth living in these institutions. The project aims to support families to raise their children, to develop community based child protection services, and to assist the orphanages to meet child protection standards. The youth leaving the orphanages receive support in starting up their life outside of institutions.

title: F.a: Empowerment toward Self-Reliance Programme (ESRP)
short_description: F.A: EMPOWERMENT TOWARD SELF-RELIANCE PROGRAMME (ESRP)
long_description: The final strategic evaluation of the LWD in 2014 has presented a significant progress in the development and empowerment effort in the target area of Kampong Spue, Kampong Chhnang, Pusat, Battambang, Siem Reap. However, there are some challenges particularly in three main areas which need to be more in focus in the project intervention. The new project is formulated according to these recommendations.    The project objectives include: 1) Enhanced local good governance through trainings and consultations for Commune Councils, Community based organisations, provincial and district officers as well as support to communities in advocacy initiatives on good governance, human rights, legal regulation etc. 2) Improved sustainable partner households' livelihoods in the communities through capacity building on agricultural and entrepreneur skills to farmers, vocational skill trainings to selected farmers as well as support Agricultural Cooperatives' (AC) and Village Banks' (VB). 3) Increased resilience of communities in disaster prone areas and promote responsiveness of Commune Committee for Disaster Management (CCDM) in Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and Climate Change Adaptation (CCA).  The key groups are marginalised, poorest and most vulnerable households and people affected by any disasters, economic shock, human rights abuses identified by the government's IDPoor system and dataset. Also those vulnerable households who are not included in the system, due to any reasons: women; children; people with disabilities; elderly; ethnic minorities.  Implementing partner: Life with Dignity (LWD) LWD is FCA's long-term and strategic partner in Cambodia. LWD has good experience in implementing integrated development and livelihood projects through rights based empowerment approach. The participation and community mobilisation experiences are the strengths of LWD, which is one of the highly appreciated local NGOs. LWD has a strong expertise in managing development work in a transparent and accountable manner.

long_description: WHAT: The project locates young deaf people who previously haven't gotten chance to educate or support themselves, and provides them access to education, livelihood and the Deaf community.WHY: 97 % of the deaf in Cambodia have never learned any language, gotten to school or met another deaf person. The deaf in Cambodia are usually dependent on their family and they live on the edge of family life and the society.HOW: By supporting deaf education, sign language and the Deaf community together with raising deaf awareness in the society, the Deaf community is able to advocate for equal human rights for the Deaf and sign language users. The project benefits the deaf entering civil society for the first time and their relatives.PARTNER ORGANISATION: The project is implemented together with Maryknoll Cambodia which is an American organization under which the Deaf Development Programme has operated since 2002.

title: F.a: Indigenous Community development Programme
short_description: F.A: INDIGENOUS COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME
long_description: Project activities are non-formal education for ethnic minorities especially women and children, producing educational material on basic health care and hygienie, culture preserving activities and indigenous livelihoods development. The ethnic minority groups of Cambodia have had very little chances to access the services, information and power in khmer-dominated Cambodia. Currently the natural resources of the minorities are exploited by powerful companies without communities themselves having much to say. The indigenous groups have the right to bi-lingual education and information, as well as preservation of their culture. The project aims to help the communities to address the social problems and to cope with the changing environment while empowered by improved literacy and knowledge. Communities have strategies to cope with changes and resist exploitation and discrimination. The beneficiaries are indigenous groups in North-east of Cambodia, especially children and elderlies. The implementing partner is International Cooperation Cambodia ICC.

title: F.a: Indigenous Community development Programme

long_description: WHAT: Non-formal education for ethnic minorities especially women and children. Producing  educational materials on basic health care and hygienie. Culture preserving activities and indigenous livelihoods development. WHY: The ethnic minority groups of Cambodia have had very little chances to access the services, information and power in khmer-dominated Cambodia. Currently the natural resources of the minorities are exploited by powerful companies and people without the communities themeselves having much to say. The indigenous groups have the right to bi-lingual education and information, as well as preservation of their culture. The project aims to help the communities to address the social problems, and to cope with the chance while empowered by literacy and knowledge. RESULTS: communities literacy levels are improved, communities have startegies to cope with change and resists exploitation and discrimination: BENEFICIARIES: indigenous groups in Norteast of Cambodia, especially children and elderlies; PARTNER: ICC

title: F.a: Kepa Mekong
short_description: F.A: KEPA MEKONG
long_description: Kepa will help its partners in the South to participate in debates concerning the roles, operating space and worldwide status of civil society, and to influence the situation in their own countries. We support the efforts of our partners to advocate on development finance, economic justiceand climate justice in our programme countries. Collaboration with civil society actors whose work in the Global South addresses our chosen themes makes our advocacy work more credible and productive, while also enabling us to combine our resources to influence global processes, often as part of international CSO networks. We can provide Kepa's partners in the South with expertise and up-to-date information on our key themes, and support their efforts to network at the national, regional and global levels. Our partner in Cambodia is Cooperation Committee for Cambodia (CCC).

title: F.a: Land and Livelihood Advocacy Development Project (LLAP)
short_description: F.A: LAND AND LIVELIHOOD ADVOCACY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT (LLAP)
long_description: Cambodia's 2001 Land Law attempted to limit encroachment into state land (technically about 80% of Cambodia's land area) while providing for legal expansion of smallholder agriculture through the distribution of up to five hectares of state land as 'social land concessions' which would be eligible for title after five years of continuous occupation and use. In 2003, Sub-Decree 19 on Social Land Concessions (SLCs) was enacted which provided for a locally initiated and managed process of planning and implementing SLCs. In late 2005, the State Land Management Sub-Decree provided the legal basis for district and provincial levels of Government to work with communes to identify and officially allocate state lands for SLCs.  Land and Advocacy Development Project (LADP) has been prepared to provide capacity building on Alternative Dispute resolution (ADR) Land Rights and Land Registration, Advocacy, Women Rights, and relevant laws to ensure that the people are aware of ADR and the responsibilities of government and other duty-bearers to fulfill, to protect and respect communities' rights. In addition, the capacity of the duty bearers will be strengthened to be able to fulfill their obligations to realise concerned communities' rights.   Objectives: Ìø To promote democratic participation and human rights at the grassroots level by educating and supporting vulnerable groups, victims of land dispute and local government (Commune Councils) to become more effective at advocating their communities' needs. Ìø To ensure the most vulnerable groups are able to access to their agriculture land and control over productive resources and assets for enhancing their livelihood activities.   Rights- holders /beneficiaries:  Approximately 1 000 households located in 25 villages at selected LWD programme areas in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhnang, Pursat, Battambang provinces will benefit from the project. The district Cadastral Commission, local authority and LWD staff will benefit from the project through capacity building on Alternative Dispute Resolution.   Implementing partner: Life with Dignity (LWD) LWD has been working together with FCA in partnership for over 20 years to improve the livelihoods of the poor and marginalised in rural Cambodia, engaging both rights-holders and duty-bearers. Since 2011, the partners have been implementing a land rights awareness project in Kampong Chhnang and Kampong Speu provinces with the aim at increasing awareness on land rights and land registration of vulnerable households who have received land through Social Land Concessions. Land rights and land registration trainings were also provided to district authority representatives, Commune Councils, village leaders, Advocacy Group and implementing partner staff in collaboration with the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction (MLMUPC).

title: F.a: Land and Livelihood Advocacy Development Project (LLAP)
short_description: F.A: LAND AND LIVELIHOOD ADVOCACY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT (LLAP)
long_description: The number of land conflicts has been significantly increased over the last 10 years in Cambodia. However, the 2001 land law was adopted following other supporting mechanisms. The land demarcation done by the relevant authorities and also the youth volunteers (following Directive 01) has not been clear especially in the land conflict areas. Both the citizens and authorities who have been involved in the conflict and conflict resolution found the difficulties in addressing the issues without statistics and lack of information. Moreover, lack of land certificate and overlapping in certificates has put the land demarcation in difficulties.The aim of Land and Livelihood Advocacy Project (LLAP) is to provide capacity building on basic Alternative Dispute resolution (ADR), Family Law, Land Rights and Land Registration, Advocacy, Women Rights, and other relevant laws through trainings, awareness raising, workshops, commune forums, meetings and dialogue. Expected results: people at the target areas are aware of ADR, their rights are fulfilled and dealing with issues is done in a peaceful manner. This will be achieved when community members are aware of the responsibilities of government and duty-bearers [such as District/Khan Cadastral Commissions (DKCC), Commune Councils (CCs), Local Authorities (LAs)] have improved capacity on Alternative Dispute Resolution and land law to fulfill, to protect and respect communities' rights. Thus the capacity of the duty-bearers will be strengthened to be able to fulfill their obligations to realise the rights of the communities. Rights- holders /beneficiaries: At least 31,787 households located in 25 villages at selected LWD programme areas in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhnang, Pursat, Battambang provinces will benefit from the project. The district Cadastral Commission, local authorities and LWD staff will benefit from the project through capacity building on Alternative Dispute Resolution. Life with Dignity (LWD) has been working together with FCA in partnership for over 20 years to improve the livelihoods of the poor and marginalized in rural Cambodia, engaging both rights-holders and duty-bearers.

title: F.a: Preventing sexual  abuse of boys
short_description: F.A: PREVENTING SEXUAL  ABUSE OF BOYS
long_description: WHAT: Work against child abuse by educating, producing information material and campaigning. An outreach programme for support and counselling as well as peer support groups are being established. WHY: Sexual abuse of young boys is a taboo in Cambodia. The victims seldom have an access to psychosocial support, which increases the risk of marginalization. The project aims in decreasing abuse and helping victims to safely re-integrate in the society.RESULTS: Local communities become aware of the ongoing sexual abuse of young boys. The victims get an access for relevant support. BENEFICIARIES: Victims of sexual abuse, other NGOs, social workers. PARTNER: First Step

title: F.a: Preventing sexual abuse of boys
short_description: F.A: PREVENTING SEXUAL ABUSE OF BOYS
long_description: The issue of male victims of sexual exploitation is a silenced problem in Cambodia. Therefore it is difficult for the victims to seek and find help and justice. To address the problem the project raises awareness and capacity of local communities, professionals and authorities regarding the ongoing sexual abuse of boys and young men. The project activities are awareness raising, trainings to social workers, police and other professionals, training of trainers, producing information material and campaigning, an outreach programme for support and counselling and peer support groups. The expected results are decreased abuse and risk of marginalization, better access to relevant psychosocial support and safe re-integration in the society for the male victims of exploitation.Beneficiaries are victims of sexual abuse, their families and caregivers, relevant professionals working with children, also other NGOs in Phnom Penh and Siem Riep. The implementing partner is First Step.

title: F.a: Promote income generation activities for persons with disabilities
short_description: F.A: PROMOTE INCOME GENERATION ACTIVITIES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES
long_description: Training on pig and poultry raising for 16 persons with a disability and providing micro loans to these persons.

title: F.a: Promote the right of people with disabilities through income generating activities for families
short_description: F.A: PROMOTE THE RIGHT OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES THROUGH INCOME GENERATING ACTIVITIES FOR FAMILIES
long_description: Raising pigs and related training. Provision of piglets to 28 persons with a disability and creating a revolving loan system.

title: F.a: Promoting child rights and protecting children
short_description: F.A: PROMOTING CHILD RIGHTS AND PROTECTING CHILDREN
long_description: The project  We protect children, do you? - Promoting Child Rights and Protecting Children from the Worst Forms of Child Labour in Cambodia  focuses on the prevention of child labor and the protection of children involved in the worst forms of child labor, in particular, children engaged in domestic work, brick factories and the entertainment industry. According to the recent statistics, there are 1,4 million working children in Cambodia. Within the most dangerous forms of labor, the working conditions are extremely damaging to health. Thousands of children lack opportunities for education because of being forced to work. This results to a cycle of illiteracy and poverty. In Cambodia, the society doesn't recognize the need to protect children from exploitation and significant gaps do exist in official child protection structures, which makes it important for NGOs to contribute in this field.  The project opposes child labor exploitation by developing groups and networks in different community sectors to monitor, investigate and refer to child rights (CR) violations. Wider audience is reached through activities that disseminate information on CR and on how to correctly respond to violations. The project also aims to contribute to the prevention of CR violations in Cambodia and to the protection and rehabilitation of victims of the violations.The project is located in both rural and urban areas in Phnom Penh and its surroundings and the provinces of Kandal, Koh Kong, Preah Sihanouk and Siem Reap.  The first project phase has been successful in establishing local level Child Protection Groups (PG), especially Child PGs in the target communities. The public awareness and debate about Child Rights and risks of the Child Labour is also increasing. This continuation phase of the project (2014-2015) will be dedicated especially to strengthening the existing Child Protection Groups as part of the local level civil societies. To ensure their continuation as independent actors, the number of members in the PGs will be increased, child and youth PG members  participation and capacity to advocate with peers strenghtened and networking and links to other local level actors  reinforced. Child and youth participation in local level decision making structures (commune/Sangkat meetings) will also be strenghtened, to increase the child and youth perspective in the decision making.

title: F.a: Promoting the capacity building of the implementing partner.
short_description: F.A: PROMOTING THE CAPACITY BUILDING OF THE IMPLEMENTING PARTNER.
long_description: Many of the FELM's partners in the Mekong region are in the process of shifting the leadership from foreign directors to the national ones. FELM supports this process by capacity building particularly to the leadership and organizational development. The project is implemented by a seconded Senior Advisor whose expertise is given for use of all the FELM development partners in the region. The project aims to strengthen the partners' capacity to be sufficient for the administrative and qualitative requirements of development projects, as well as to professional management of the organization itself. The focus is in strengthening the capacity of the local directors and management in order to ensure the smooth shift of ownership in the organisations. The activities vary depending on the needs of each organization but include e.g. training and coaching especially for the senior management (board members, executive directors, management teams) and middle management (e.g. project managers). Also some training sessions for the whole staff are provided. The coaching is confidential in nature, thus the reporting of the results in details is left in the partner organization's consideration. The beneficiaries of the project are first the directors and leaders and through them the whole staff and finally all the people and stakeholders for whom the organisations exist.

title: F.a: Promoting the capacity building of the implementing partner.
short_description: F.A: PROMOTING THE CAPACITY BUILDING OF THE IMPLEMENTING PARTNER.
long_description: WHAT: Assessing and supporting partners in organisational development. Training and other forms of capasity building in management and leadership issues.

title: F.a: Reinforcement of local communities and networking with activists to stop the Areng hydro dam
short_description: F.A: REINFORCEMENT OF LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND NETWORKING WITH ACTIVISTS TO STOP THE ARENG HYDRO DAM
long_description: Mother Nature organization, a volunteer movement made up of local indigenous communities, youth activists, and members of civil society, has been successfully opposing the proposed Areng hydroelectric dam, which would seriously damage the unique biodiversity of the Central Cardamom Protected Forest in Koh Kong province, and seriously infringe on the human rights of local indigenous communities. During this project, Mother Nature will continue taking advantage of its rapport with influential community members to ensure that the communities at large are fully informed of what their rights are, and feel empowered enough to publicly oppose the project. Also, Mother Nature will increase its media campaign to highlight the massive inconsistencies with the dam, also highlighting the fact that it has been classed as 'uneconomical' by two large dam builders. This will be done through the use of a newly created network, which will concentrate its efforts in punctual, public, and innovative activities / campaigns. Mother Nature organization was created in February 2013 in the village of Ta Tay Leu, Koh Kong province, which was seeing massive deforestation of its ancient sacred spirit forests. Mother Nature has successfully campaigned against illegal logging. The goals of Mother Nature are: 1) To prevent the proposed Chhay Areng hydroelectric dam, or any other-large scale development projects, from being approved inside the Central Cardamom Protected Forest (CCPF); 2) Protect, reinforce, and promote the unique culture, traditions, and livelihoods of the Cardamom Mountain's remaining forest-dependant indigenous communities; 3) Lobby the Cambodian government to declare the whole of the CCPF area a UNESCO World Heritage Site; 4) Increase international pressure on protecting the forest area by leveraging national and international civil society networks, social media and mainstream media; 5) Encourage tourists and researchers to visit the Cardamoms in order to learn more about these unique and endangered landscapes as well as help create jobs and income in the area; 6) To become Cambodia's first green movement, made of environmentally aware Cambodians. Mother Nature does not have paid full-time personnel. As a volunteer-led non-profit movement, the members agree to remuneration that covers only their basic living costs, and no salaries are paid out. www.mothernature.pm

title: F.a: Reinforcement of local communities and networking with activists to stop the Areng hydro dam
short_description: F.A: REINFORCEMENT OF LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND NETWORKING WITH ACTIVISTS TO STOP THE ARENG HYDRO DAM
long_description: Mother Nature organization, a volunteer movement made up of local indigenous communities, youth activists, and members of civil society, has been successfully opposing the proposed Areng hydroelectric dam, which would seriously damage the unique biodiversity of the Central Cardamom Protected Forest in Koh Kong province, and seriously infringe on the human rights of local indigenous communities. With the strong relationship with members of the local communities and other activist groups, effective one-step-ahead-approach, and through the use of a savvy media campaign, Mother Nature has been able to delay the process and make the Areng Valley a talking point. During this project, Mother Nature will continue taking advantage of its rapport with influential community members to ensure that the communities at large are fully informed of what their rights are, and feel empowered enough (with the necessary tools, contacts and strategies) to publicly oppose the project. Also, Mother Nature will increase its media campaign to highlight the massive inconsistencies with the dam, pointing at not just the usual human rights violations and the massive ecological footprint, but also highlighting the fact that it has been classed as 'uneconomical' by two large dam builders. This will be done through the use of a newly created network, which will concentrate its efforts in punctual, public, and innovative activities / campaigns. Mother Nature organization was created in February 2013 in the village of Ta Tay Leu, Koh Kong province, which was seeing massive deforestation of its ancient sacred spirit forests. Mother Nature has successfully campaigned agaist illegal logging, and has built a broad-based movement to stop the proposed Chhay Areng dam, as it would severely damage the unique biodiversity of the area and seriously infringe on the human rights of local indigenous communities. The goals of Mother Nature are: 1) To prevent the proposed Chhay Areng hydroelectric dam, or any other-large scale development projects, from being approved inside the Central Cardamom Protected Forest (CCPF); 2) Protect, reinforce, and promote the unique culture, traditions, and livelihoods of the Cardamom Mountain s remaining forest-dependant indigenous communities; 3) Lobby the Cambodian government to declare the whole of the CCPF area a UNESCO World Heritage Site; 4) Increase international pressure on protecting the forest area by leveraging national and international civil society networks, social media and mainstream media; 5) Encourage tourists and researchers to visit the Cardamoms in order to learn more about these unique and endangered landscapes as well as help create jobs and income in the area; 6) To become Cambodia's first green movement, made of environmentally aware Cambodians. Mother Nature does not have paid full-time personnel. As a volunteer-led non-profit movement, the members agree to remuneration that covers only their basic living costs, and no salaries are pai

long_description: Integrated Disaster Preparedness. To reduce impact of disasters on vulnerable population and increase capacity of the population to respond and recover also off the wider socio- economical changes.

title: F.a: Strenghtening of Food Security
short_description: F.A: STRENGHTENING OF FOOD SECURITY
long_description: The project focuses on training on good hygiene practices, healthy diet, organic farming and raising of animals. Support is also given to fruit trees planting, construction of fish ponds and water filters. Many children in Kampong Thom are malnourished, often due to lack of food but also because of the low nutritional value of the food that they are given, as well as poor hygiene and lack of information about healthy diet. The beneficiaries, poor families in Kampong Thom province, will have enhanced food quantity and quality, improved hygiene practices, raised level of knowledge in food related issues and increased awareness of healthy diet and hygiene. New sustainable food production methods are applied. The implementing partner is Church World Service (CWS).

title: F.a: Strenghtening of Food Security
short_description: F.A: STRENGHTENING OF FOOD SECURITY
long_description: WHAT: training on good hygiene practices, healthy diet, organic farming, animal raising. Planting fruit trees, constructing fish ponds WHY: many children in Kampong Thom are malnourished due to lack of food, bad hygienen and lack of information about healthy diet. Also, the big floods in 2011 contributed to the misery of the communities by destroying the rice field (including seed rice). CWS Cambodia aims to enhance the food quantity and quality in the communities and improve the hygiene practices and level of knowledge in food related issues. RESULTS: increased awareness about healthy diet and hygiene. Poor families have access to healthy and suffcient food. New sustainable food production methods are applied BENEFICIARIES: Poor families in Kampong Thom, children in the communities

long_description: 15 persons with a spinal cord injury in Battambang Cambodia are trained on running their own small business and will receive some start-up capital to start their business of livestock raising, small business e.g. grocery selling or accessible Tuktuk business. Abilis self-care manual for the spinal cord injured will be translated into Khmer by a person with a disability and 60 persons with a spinal cord injury will benefit from the information in the manual.

title: F.a: Women In Action project (WIN)
short_description: F.A: WOMEN IN ACTION PROJECT (WIN)
long_description: Deep-rooted gender inequalities and gender-based violence (GBV) are pervasive in Cambodian society, particularly in areas where poverty is widespread; unemployment is high; and education levels are low. The low levels of literacy and education limit women's options for generating sufficient income for decent living which exposes them and their children to the risk of exploitation and violence. In addition, low family incomes and social attitudes all combine to create numerous barriers to girls attending or remaining in school, causing them to drop out before completing their basic education and thereby increasing their vulnerability. Women and girls also have less voice and thus little influence in decision-making processes in their communities due to prevailing gender stereotypes.  The target area of the project is Siem Reap province which is one of the poorest provinces of Cambodia, with a high number of female-headed households, most of whom are poor and under considerable economic and social stress.   Project objectives include: Ìø Empowered women are able to generate income through group businesses and small enterprises Ìø Clusters of savings groups formed into Federations in the target areas to provide support to vulnerable women to curb financial crisis and all forms of violence Ìø Girls from poor families living in the target areas are empowered through access to education (scholarships, vocational and life skills training)     Rights-holders /beneficiaries:  The most vulnerable women and girls including women from poor families, landless and women recovering from violence; men and boys will also benefit directly and indirectly from saving groups and community awareness; CWCC staff, family members of targeted women, community members, partner NGOs and members of local authorities.   Implementing partner:  The Cambodia Women's Crisis Centre (CWCC) is a recognised, local non-governmental organisation established in 1997 with the aim of combatting all forms of violence against women and children. CWCC endeavours to support and empower the survivors to realise their rights and to lead a dignified life. CWCC has extensive experience in responding to the needs of the most vulnerable groups of society through a wide variety of interventions, including social assistance, legal protection, community organising, economic empowerment through skills training and small business loans, and promotion of access to secondary education for vulnerable girls.

title: F.a: Women In Action project (WIN)
short_description: F.A: WOMEN IN ACTION PROJECT (WIN)
long_description: Deep-rooted gender inequalities and gender-based violence (GBV) are pervasive in Cambodian society, particularly in areas where poverty is widespread; unemployment is high; and education levels are low. The low levels of literacy and education limit women's options for generating sufficient income for decent living which exposes them and their children to the risk of exploitation and violence. In addition, low family incomes and social attitudes all combine to create numerous barriers to girls attending or remaining in school, causing them to drop out before completing their basic education and thereby increasing their vulnerability. Women and girls also have less voice and thus little influence in decision-making processes in their communities due to prevailing gender stereotypes.The target area of the project is Siem Reap province which is one of the poorest provinces of Cambodia, with a high number of female-headed households, most of whom are poor and under considerable economic and social stress. Expected results:Ìø 20 saving schemes (saving for change) established with active participation from targeted communities and income generation activities/businesses identified and selected based on the result of the market surveyÌø Girls from poor families living in target communities received a scholarship package so they can continue their study at public schoolÌø Target communities gradually improved understanding of the importance of girl's access to educationÌø Youth club established and capacity building provided to become focal group in providing awareness campaigns to community members Rights-holders /beneficiaries: The most vulnerable women and girls including women from poor families, landless and women recovering from violence; men and boys will also benefit directly and indirectly from saving groups and community awareness; CWCC staff, family members of targeted women, community members, partner NGOs and members of local authorities. Implementing partner: The Cambodia Women's Crisis Centre (CWCC) is a local non-governmental organisation with the aim of combatting all forms of violence against women and children. CWCC has extensive experience in responding to the needs of the most vulnerable groups of society through variety of interventions, including social assistance, legal protection, community organising, economic empowerment through skills training and small business loans and promotion of access to secondary education for girls.

title: Feed the Future  Cambodia Impact Evaluation and Strengthening Local Capacity to Monitor and Evaluate Food Security Programs - Agricultural Sector Capa
short_description: FEED THE FUTURE  CAMBODIA IMPACT EVALUATION AND STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY TO MONITOR AND EVALUATE FOOD SECURITY PROGRAMS - AGRICULTURAL SECTOR CAPA
long_description: The Cambodia Impact Evaluation and Strengthening Local Capacity to Monitor and Evaluate Food Security Programs will implement an impact evaluation of Feed the Future programming as well as train local professionals on conducting impact evaluations and research and writing food-security case studies. Michigan State University (MSU), the project's implementer, will partner with the Royal University of Agriculture and the Cambodian Development Resource Institute on this program. With FY 2014 funding, MSU will provide evaluation training to at least 20 mid-career professionals working at local institutions involved in the food-security sector; guide these trainees in conducting a policy-focused case study; and continue financial and academic support for four Cambodian scholarship recipients studying at U.S. and Cambodian universities. MSU will also research and write additional case studies. This project advances USAID's evaluation policy and Feed the Future evaluation requirements.

title: Feed the Future  Cambodia Impact Evaluation and Strengthening Local Capacity to Monitor and Evaluate Food Security Programs - Agricultural Sector Capa
short_description: FEED THE FUTURE  CAMBODIA IMPACT EVALUATION AND STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY TO MONITOR AND EVALUATE FOOD SECURITY PROGRAMS - AGRICULTURAL SECTOR CAPA
long_description: The Cambodia Impact Evaluation and Strengthening Local Capacity to Monitor and Evaluate Food Security Programs will implement an impact evaluation of Feed the Future programming as well as train local professionals on conducting impact evaluations and research and writing food-security case studies. Michigan State University (MSU), the projects implementer, will partner with the Royal University of Agriculture and the Cambodian Development Resource Institute on this program. With FY 2014 funding, MSU will provide evaluation training to at least 20 mid-career professionals working at local institutions involved in the food-security sector; guide these trainees in conducting a policy-focused case study; and continue financial and academic support for four Cambodian scholarship recipients studying at U.S. and Cambodian universities. MSU will also research and write additional case studies. This project advances USAIDs evaluation policy and Feed the Future evaluation requirements.

title: Financial Sector Program (cluster; subloan III)
short_description: FINANCIAL SECTOR PROGRAM (CLUSTER; SUBLOAN III)
long_description: The overall objective of the FSPL is to promote the development of a sound, market-based financial system to enhance resource mobilization and support sustainable economic growth by establishing a foundation for the banking and insurance sectors and developing the financial market. The FSPL adopted a program cluster approach with three subprograms based on ADB's program lending policies. Each succeeding subprogram was to be processed sequentially upon completion of the preceding subprogram.Subprogram III will focus on (i) enhancing the banking sector infrastructure, (ii) enacting commercial laws and building capacity, (iii) laying the foundations for the inter-bank and money markets, and (iv) developing the accounting and auditing practices.

title: Financial Sector Program (Subprogram II)
short_description: FINANCIAL SECTOR PROGRAM (SUBPROGRAM II)
long_description: This is the second of three subprograms under FSPL which  aims to promote the development of a sound, market-based financial system to support enhanced mobilization and sustainable economic growth by establishing a foundation for the banking and insurance sector as well as financial market development. FSPL will focus on the following activities: (i) enhancing banking intermediation and public confidence by establishing and strengthening banking supervision, development of key information infrastructure and safety net, and building capacity in both public and private sectors by reinforcing capacity building institutions; (ii) establishing legal and regulatory frameworks for insurance development by institutionalizing and supervisory system and prudential regulations, fostering private sector development in the insurance business, and developing compulsory insurance; (iii) laying foundation for the development of interbank and money markets through public-private sector partnership and establishing a basic legal framework; and (iv) developing financial market infrastructure by establishing common accounting standards and enforcement mechanisms and promulgating laws to underpin the commercial activities and financial markets.

title: Fishery Valuation in Laos and Cambodia
short_description: FISHERY VALUATION IN LAOS AND CAMBODIA
long_description: Freshwater capture fisheries in the Lower Mekong Basin provide 47 to 80% of the animal protein consumed, as well as livelihood opportunities on a large scale. However in absence of a solid estimate of the total economic value of these fisheries, their importance remains very poorly recognized by institutions and in development plans, which hampers rural development. Accordingly, the overall aim of this project is to quantify the multiple values of fish resources, interpret findings, analyse implications, and convey high level results and implications to national decision-makers, development agencies and local actors, for sustainable and improved rural livelihoods. This information should provide essential guidance for future agriculture and rural development programs aimed at improving welfare in the Mekong Basin.

title: Focused Monitoring and Defense of Human Rights in Cambodia - Human Rights
short_description: FOCUSED MONITORING AND DEFENSE OF HUMAN RIGHTS IN CAMBODIA - HUMAN RIGHTS
long_description: The Documentation Center - Cambodia (DC-Cam) will continue to be the authoritative Cambodian source for information and educational materials on the Khmer Rouge genocide. DC-Cam houses the worlds largest archive of documentation on the Khmer Rouge period, which is accessible to researchers and members of the public. These documents provide a significant source of evidence for the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia (ECCC). With FY 2014 funds, DC-Cam will continue to facilitate the participation of Khmer Rouge survivors as witnesses at the ECCCs trials; improve instruction on the Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodian public schools and universities; publish a regular magazine and several books; start creating digital copies of Khmer Rouge era documents; and make progress towards the establishment of a permanent museum on the Khmer Rouge era. These activities will help preserve Cambodias historical memory about its tragic past.

title: Focused Monitoring and Defense of Human Rights in Cambodia - Program Design and Learning
short_description: FOCUSED MONITORING AND DEFENSE OF HUMAN RIGHTS IN CAMBODIA - PROGRAM DESIGN AND LEARNING
long_description: The Documentation Center - Cambodia (DC-Cam) will continue to be the authoritative Cambodian source for information and educational materials on the Khmer Rouge genocide. DC-Cam houses the world's largest archive of documentation on the Khmer Rouge period, which is accessible to researchers and members of the public. These documents provide a significant source of evidence for the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia (ECCC). With FY 2014 funds, DC-Cam will continue to facilitate the participation of Khmer Rouge survivors as witnesses at the ECCC's trials; improve instruction on the Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodian public schools and universities; publish a regular magazine and several books; start creating digital copies of Khmer Rouge era documents; and make progress towards the establishment of a permanent museum on the Khmer Rouge era. These activities will help preserve Cambodia's historical memory about its tragic past.

title: Food Security and Climate Change in Cambodia
short_description: FOOD SECURITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN CAMBODIA
long_description: Cambodia is one of the poorest countries in Asia. About 70% of the population depends on agriculture for a living. Food insecurity affects rural people in particular, and the number of people who are food insecure is growing. Among Southeast Asian countries, Cambodia is also one of the most vulnerable to climate change. Given the country s dependence on agriculture and natural resources, tackling climate change and food security together is essential. This project will address the interface between food security and climate change through two important issues: land use and water governance. The research agenda will be carried out through three interrelated components: competitive research grants (projects and fellowships); applied research conducted by the Learning Institute research team; and the provision of research support services for disseminating research results to policymakers and other stakeholders.

title: Food Security and Climate Change in Cambodia
short_description: FOOD SECURITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN CAMBODIA
long_description: Cambodia is one of the poorest countries in Asia. About 70% of the population depends on agriculture for a living. Food insecurity affects rural people in particular, and the number of people who are food insecure is growing. Among Southeast Asian countries, Cambodia is also one of the most vulnerable to climate change. Given the country's dependence on agriculture and natural resources, tackling climate change and food security together is essential. title: Forest restoration and water availability for smart agriculture: a case study of Cambodia (FRAWASA)
short_description: FOREST RESTORATION AND WATER AVAILABILITY FOR SMART AGRICULTURE: A CASE STUDY OF CAMBODIA (FRAWASA)
long_description: Forest degradation and climate change are a serious environmental problem in much of the tropics,threatening biodiversity, ecosystem services and livelihoods of local people. Replacement of native vegetationby industrial plantations of fast-growing exotic trees, such as eucalypts, lead to depletion of soil waterreserves, affecting nearby agricultural areas. A representative case is Cambodia, where 80% of thepopulation lives in rural areas and are dependent on rainfed agriculture and resources from forests for theirlivelihood. Taking a landscape perpective, and using a process-based climate-ecosystem model in combinationwith extensive field measurements and distributed data, we will assess the benefits and risks of alternativemanagement choices for forest restoration and smart (i.e. climate adapted) agriculture for the mainbioclimatic zones of Cambodia and for the country as a whole, highlighting climate-related risks such asdroughts and wildfires, and accounting for uncertainty. Alternative management scenarios will be developedin consultation with farmers, foresters, local and national authorities and other stakeholders, with whomfindings will also be disseminated and discussed. Our overall goal is to provide new system understanding andquantitative assessment as a basis for the science-based management and restoration of Cambodianlandscapes under climate change, contributing to a national policy process targetting the sustainable use ofland.

title: Frame agreement with NGO (Fida Int.)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FIDA INT.)
long_description: Community Health Education Programme. The programme aims to empower a local partner for independent community development work. Fida's partner in Cambodia is Cambodia Global Action (CGA), an NGO owned by the Assemblies of God church of Cambodia (AOG). Fida and CGA work together in the local communities, which provide the partner with hands-on training in community development. The main approach used is that of Community Health Education (CHE). The programme has expanded to over 70 villages and will soon cover up to 130 villages altogether. Through the programme, the partner's capacities in community development grow and the organization will be able to carry out community development projects independently. In addition, CGA will be able to multiply the effect through training local churches on CHE. As a result communities all over Cambodia will be holistically changed.

title: Frame agreement with NGO (FIDIDA)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FIDIDA)
long_description: Deaf Empowerment and Awareness in Cambodia. WHAT: The project locates and provides basic education and access to the Deaf community to young deaf people who haven t previously gotten chance to educate or to support themselves.WHY: 97 % of the deaf in Cambodia have never learned any language, gotten to school or met another deaf person. The deaf in Cambodia are usually dependent on their family and they live on the edge of family life and the society.HOW: By supporting deaf education, sign language and the Deaf community together with raising deaf awareness in the society, the Deaf community is able to advocate for equal human rights for the Deaf and sign language users. The project benefits the deaf entering civil society for the first time and their relatives.PARTNER ORGANISATION: The project is implemented together with Maryknoll Cambodia which is an American organization under which the Deaf Development Programme has operated since 2002.

title: Frame Agreement with NGO (Finn Church Aid)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FINN CHURCH AID)
long_description: Based on the findings of the evaluation conducted in August-Sept 2014, and recommendations from the FCA livelihood expert during the field visits, together with consultative discussions with LWD programme management and field staff, the key challenges of women were identified as: lack of economic opportunities and social participation due to limited access to markets and networking, low business skills, poor knowledge on entrepreneurship and decision-making in both household and community. Particularly, the Women Agriculture Cooperatives (WACs) still have limited understanding on collective business concept. Group capital mobilisation appears to be needed for expansion of collective business.Responding to these challenges, the project will promote entrepreneurship, continue to support vulnerable women to play an active role to lead and manage Agriculture Cooperatives and establish market linkages through value chain concepts. The project also improves economic status of women through collective business groups, including proper business plans. It also strengthens institutional development through networking and advocacy for business opportunities.   The excepted results are:Ìø Improved business capacity of women leaders in micro and small business group through provision of capacity building and mentoring on business plan to WAC management committee and small business groups and setting up the operational model for micro and small business groups.Ìø Strengthen business networking of WACs and business actors and duty-bearersÌø Improve project staff capacity in providing business mentoring; Training course on the business and value chain based on the capacity assessment aimed at passing on this knowledge and related skills to WACs.Rights-holders /beneficiaries: At least 5000 households, the most vulnerable women, youth and AC smallholders. Implementing partner: Life with Dignity (LWD) is FCA's long-term and strategic partner in Cambodia. LWD has good experience in implementing integrated development and livelihood projects through rights based empowerment approach. The participation and community mobilisation experiences are the strengths of LWD, which is one of the highly appreciated local NGOs. LWD has a strong expertise in managing development work in a transparent and accountable manner. Technical or specialised institutes, especially on business sector, will be hired to conduct a series of capacity building and mentoring to agricultural cooperatives to ensure that the business plan and operation are smoothly applied and benefit AC members, particularly smallholders.

title: Frame Agreement with NGO (Finn Church Aid)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FINN CHURCH AID)
long_description: By building capacity among Cambodian youth, KYA is empowering the next generation of leaders and agents of change. In Cambodia, 65 % of the population is under age of 30, and therefore youth empowerment is an imperative. KYA is dedicated to advocate the government with active and meaningful participation of youth in the decision-making and political process. Robust youth participation is perhaps the strongest mechanism that builds a more democratic society in Cambodia. KYA s core objectives are focused on empowering vulnerable youth, who are at-risk because of conditions such as poverty, limited access to education, unemployment, disability, and/or sickness.Objectives:Ìø To enhance space and opportunities for youth to be actively involved in the society and policy making process Ìø To increase knowledge, skills and awareness of youth on human rights, education and peace.Activities: Ìø Capacity Building in advocacy skills, thematic contents, media advocacy skills, team building, research skills, public speaking, fundraising strategy and proposal writing, constitutional law and law on peaceful assemblyÌø The launch, assembly and meetings of Cambodia Changemaker Network Ìø Monthly advocacy or awareness activity that the network members will implement e.g. via social media and YouTube, which will support the main campaign (2 per year) decided by the network.Rights- holders /beneficiaries: Cambodia Changemaker Network has identified the core to establish the network in 2014, consisting of 22 members (from 7 provinces). KYA has established earlier about 60 Community Youth Networks (CYNs) all over the country (including some of FCA's existing target areas) which actively participate in community development. The youth group members aged 15-35 years are the rights-holders of the project, as well as the wide youth population in Cambodia through campaigns, awareness raising, etc. In addition, the local authorities, government and UN will be targeted.Implementing partner:Khmer Youth Association (KYA) is a humanitarian, non-governmental and non-partisan organization established in 1992, registered by the Ministry of Interior (MoI), Cambodia. KYA is Cambodia's leading non-partisan youth organization working on issues of human rights, democracy, gender equality, and sustainable development. In October 2013 FCA facilitated an exposure visit for a group of Cambodian youth, including one FCA employee and KYA staff, to Finland. The aim was to share knowledge and experiences of Changemaker network in Finland and Changemaker International. Since November 2013, FCA has been consulted on the development of Changemaker network in Cambodia.

title: Frame Agreement with NGO (Finn Church Aid)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FINN CHURCH AID)
long_description: Cambodia's 2001 Land Law attempted to limit encroachment into state land (technically about 80% of Cambodia's land area) while providing for legal expansion of smallholder agriculture through the distribution of up to five hectares of state land as 'social land concessions' which would be eligible for title after five years of continuous occupation and use. In 2003, Sub-Decree 19 on Social Land Concessions (SLCs) was enacted which provided for a locally initiated and managed process of planning and implementing SLCs. In late 2005, the State Land Management Sub-Decree provided the legal basis for district and provincial levels of Government to work with communes to identify and officially allocate state lands for SLCs.Land and Advocacy Development Project (LADP) has been prepared to provide capacity building on Alternative Dispute resolution (ADR) Land Rights and Land Registration, Advocacy, Women Rights, and relevant laws to ensure that the people are aware of ADR and the responsibilities of government and other duty-bearers to fulfill, to protect and respect communities' rights. In addition, the capacity of the duty bearers will be strengthened to be able to fulfill their obligations to realise concerned communities' rights. Objectives:Ìø To promote democratic participation and human rights at the grassroots level by educating and supporting vulnerable groups, victims of land dispute and local government (Commune Councils) to become more effective at advocating their communities' needs.Ìø To ensure the most vulnerable groups are able to access to their agriculture land and control over productive resources and assets for enhancing their livelihood activities. Rights- holders /beneficiaries: Approximately 1 000 households located in 25 villages at selected LWD programme areas in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhnang, Pursat, Battambang provinces will benefit from the project. The district Cadastral Commission, local authority and LWD staff will benefit from the project through capacity building on Alternative Dispute Resolution. Implementing partner: Life with Dignity (LWD)LWD has been working together with FCA in partnership for over 20 years to improve the livelihoods of the poor and marginalised in rural Cambodia, engaging both rights-holders and duty-bearers. Since 2011, the partners have been implementing a land rights awareness project in Kampong Chhnang and Kampong Speu provinces with the aim at increasing awareness on land rights and land registration of vulnerable households who have received land through Social Land Concessions. Land rights and land registration trainings were also provided to district authority representatives, Commune Councils, village leaders, Advocacy Group and implementing partner staff in collaboration with the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction (MLMUPC).

title: Frame Agreement with NGO (Finn Church Aid)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FINN CHURCH AID)
long_description: Deep-rooted gender inequalities and gender-based violence (GBV) are pervasive in Cambodian society, particularly in areas where poverty is widespread; unemployment is high; and education levels are low. The low levels of literacy and education limit women's options for generating sufficient income for decent living which exposes them and their children to the risk of exploitation and violence. In addition, low family incomes and social attitudes all combine to create numerous barriers to girls attending or remaining in school, causing them to drop out before completing their basic education and thereby increasing their vulnerability. Women and girls also have less voice and thus little influence in decision-making processes in their communities due to prevailing gender stereotypes.The target area of the project is Siem Reap province which is one of the poorest provinces of Cambodia, with a high number of female-headed households, most of whom are poor and under considerable economic and social stress. Project objectives include:Ìø Empowered women are able to generate income through group businesses and small enterprisesÌø Clusters of savings groups formed into Federations in the target areas to provide support to vulnerable women to curb financial crisis and all forms of violenceÌø Girls from poor families living in the target areas are empowered through access to education (scholarships, vocational and life skills training)  Rights-holders /beneficiaries: The most vulnerable women and girls including women from poor families, landless and women recovering from violence; men and boys will also benefit directly and indirectly from saving groups and community awareness; CWCC staff, family members of targeted women, community members, partner NGOs and members of local authorities. Implementing partner: The Cambodia Women's Crisis Centre (CWCC) is a recognised, local non-governmental organisation established in 1997 with the aim of combatting all forms of violence against women and children. CWCC endeavours to support and empower the survivors to realise their rights and to lead a dignified life. CWCC has extensive experience in responding to the needs of the most vulnerable groups of society through a wide variety of interventions, including social assistance, legal protection, community organising, economic empowerment through skills training and small business loans, and promotion of access to secondary education for vulnerable girls.

title: Frame Agreement with NGO (Finn Church Aid)
short_description: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (FINN CHURCH AID)
long_description: The final strategic evaluation of the LWD in 2014 has presented a significant progress in the development and empowerment effort in the target area of Kampong Spue, Kampong Chhnang, Pusat, Battambang, Siem Reap. However, there are some challenges particularly in three main areas which need to be more in focus in the project intervention. The new project is formulated according to these recommendations.  The project objectives include:1) Enhanced local good governance through trainings and consultations for Commune Councils, Community based organisations, provincial and district officers as well as support to communities in advocacy initiatives on good governance, human rights, legal regulation etc.2) Improved sustainable partner households' livelihoods in the communities through capacity building on agricultural and entrepreneur skills to farmers, vocational skill trainings to selected farmers as well as support Agricultural Cooperatives' (AC) and Village Banks' (VB).3) Increased resilience of communities in disaster prone areas and promote responsiveness of Commune Committee for Disaster Management (CCDM) in Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and Climate Change Adaptation (CCA).The key groups are marginalised, poorest and most vulnerable households and people affected by any disasters, economic shock, human rights abuses identified by the government's IDPoor system and dataset. Also those vulnerable households who are not included in the system, due to any reasons: women; children; people with disabilities; elderly; ethnic minorities.Implementing partner: Life with Dignity (LWD)LWD is FCA's long-term and strategic partner in Cambodia. LWD has good experience in implementing integrated development and livelihood projects through rights based empowerment approach. The participation and community mobilisation experiences are the strengths of LWD, which is one of the highly appreciated local NGOs. LWD has a strong expertise in managing development work in a transparent and accountable manner.

long_description: To improve the health of the most vulnerable population, so that the communities could better cope with the health threaths, disasters and the envoronmental changes and to reduce the risks.
